This subsequently leads to cell lysis, tissue damage or loss of function through mechanisms such as 1. complement activation via the classical complement pathway 2. Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity or 3. anti-receptor activity.__###newline###__ The activation of the complement system results in opsonization, the agglutination of red blood cells, cell lysis, and cell death. These reactions usually take between 2 and 24 hours to develop.

Type II hypersensitivity is an antibody-mediated process where IgG and IgM antibodies target antigens on cells or extracellular material leading to cell damage, lysis, or loss of function. This can happen via complement activation through the classical complement pathway, antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity, or anti-receptor activity. The activation of the complement system can result in opsonization, the agglutination of red blood cells, cell lysis, and cell death. These reactions usually take between 2 and 24 hours to develop.
What is type III hypersensitivity?

Type III hypersensitivity, in the Gell and Coombs classification of allergic reactions, occurs when there is accumulation of immune complexes that have not been adequately cleared by innate immune cells, giving rise to an inflammatory response and attraction of leukocytes. There are three steps that lead to this response. The first step is immune complex formation, which involves the binding of antigens to antibodies to form mobile immune complexes. The second step is immune complex deposition, during which the complexes leave the plasma and are deposited into tissues. Finally, the third step is the inflammatory reaction, during which the classical pathway is activated and macrophages and neutrophils are recruited to the affected tissues. Such reactions may progress to immune complex diseases.

Type III hypersensitivity is a type of allergic reaction classified by Gell and Coombs. It happens when immune complexes aren't adequately cleared by innate immune cells, leading to an inflammatory response. There are three steps in this response. The first step involves the formation of immune complexes through binding of antigens to antibodies. The second step is the deposition of these immune complexes from the plasma into tissues. The last step encompasses the activation of the classical pathway which induces an inflammatory reaction, with macrophages and neutrophils being recruited to the affected tissues. This form of hypersensitivity can progress to immune complex diseases.
What is type IV hypersensitivity?

Type IV hypersensitivity, in the Gell and Coombs classification of allergic reactions, often called delayed-type hypersensitivity, is a type of hypersensitivity reaction that can take a day or more to develop. Unlike the other types, it is not humoral but rather is a type of cell-mediated response. This response involves the interaction of T cells, monocytes, and macrophages. This reaction is caused when CD4\u207a T\u20951 cells recognize foreign antigen in a complex with the MHC class II on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. These can be macrophages that secrete IL-12, which stimulates the proliferation of further CD4\u207a T\u20951 cells. CD4\u207a T cells secrete IL-2 and interferon gamma, inducing the further release of other T\u20951 cytokines, thus mediating the immune response. Activated CD8\u207a T cells destroy target cells on contact, whereas activated macrophages produce hydrolytic enzymes and, on presentation with certain intracellular pathogens, transform into multinucleated giant cells.

Type IV hypersensitivity, often called delayed-type hypersensitivity, is a type of allergic reaction that usually takes a day or more to develop. Unlike other types of hypersensitivity reactions, it is cell-mediated, not humoral. The reaction involves T cells, monocytes, and macrophages and occurs when CD4\u207a T\u20951 cells recognize a foreign antigen. These cells secrete IL-2 and interferon gamma, mediating the immune response. Activated CD8\u207a T cells destroy target cells on contact, while activated macrophages produce hydrolytic enzymes and fend off certain intracellular pathogens by transforming into multinucleated giant cells.
What are autoimmune diseases?
Autoimmune diseases are conditions in which your immune system mistakenly damages healthy cells in your body. Types include rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, and some thyroid conditions.

Autoimmune diseases are conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells in the body. Some examples of these diseases are rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, and certain thyroid conditions.
What are immunodeficiency diseases?
Immunodeficiency disorders are either congenital or acquired. A congenital, or primary, disorder is one you were born with. An acquired, or secondary, disorder is one you get later in life.

Immunodeficiency diseases are disorders where the immune system is less able to protect the body from infections, cancer, or diseases. These disorders can either be congenital, which means a person is born with them, or acquired, which means they are obtained later in life.
What is allergy?

Allergies, also known as allergic diseases, are various conditions caused by hypersensitivity of the immune system to typically harmless substances in the environment. These diseases include hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis. Symptoms may include red eyes, an itchy rash, sneezing, coughing, a runny nose, shortness of breath, or swelling. Note that food intolerances and food poisoning are separate conditions. Common allergens include pollen and certain foods. Metals and other substances may also cause such problems. Food, insect stings, and medications are common causes of severe reactions. Their development is due to both genetic and environmental factors. The underlying mechanism involves immunoglobulin E antibodies, part of the body's immune system, binding to an allergen and then to a receptor on mast cells or basophils where it triggers the release of inflammatory chemicals such as histamine.

Allergy, also known as allergic disease, arises from the hypersensitivity of the immune system to typically harmless substances in the environment. Symptoms of allergies can include red eyes, an itchy rash, sneezing, coughing, a runny nose, shortness of breath, or swelling. Common causes of these allergies are pollen, certain foods, metals, insect stings, and medications. The process causing allergies involves immunoglobulin E antibodies, part of the body's immune system, binding to an allergen and then to a receptor on mast cells or basophils, triggering the release of inflammatory chemicals like histamine. It's important to know that there's a difference between food intolerances, food poisoning, and food allergies.
What is atopy?

Atopy is the tendency to produce an exaggerated immunoglobulin E immune response to otherwise harmless substances in the environment. Allergic diseases are clinical manifestations of such inappropriate, atopic responses. Atopy may have a hereditary component, although contact with the allergen or irritant must occur before the hypersensitivity reaction can develop. Maternal psychological trauma in utero may also be a strong indicator for development of atopy. The term atopy was coined by Arthur F. Coca and Robert Cooke in 1923. Many physicians and scientists use the term \"atopy\" for any IgE-mediated reaction, but many pediatricians reserve the word \"atopy\" for a genetically mediated predisposition to an excessive IgE reaction. The term is from Greek \u1f00\u03c4\u03bf\u03c0\u03af\u03b1 meaning \"the state of being out of place\", \"absurdity\".

Atopy refers to the genetically predisposed tendency of some individuals to have an exaggerated immunoglobulin E (IgE) immune response to otherwise harmless substances in their surroundings. This inappropriate reaction can lead to allergic diseases. It's crucial to note that contact with the allergen is necessary for this hypersensitivity reaction to develop, and maternal psychological trauma during pregnancy can influence the development of atopy. Some professionals use 'atopy' to describe any IgE-mediated reaction, while others limit the term exclusively to genetic predispositions leading to heavy IgE reactions. The term 'atopy' is derived from Greek, signifying 'being out of place' or 'absurdity'.
What is asthma?

Asthma is a long-term inflammatory disease of the airways of the lungs. It is characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and easily triggered bronchospasms. Symptoms include episodes of wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. These may occur a few times a day or a few times per week. Depending on the person, asthma symptoms may become worse at night or with exercise. Asthma is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Environmental factors include exposure to air pollution and allergens. Other potential triggers include medications such as aspirin and beta blockers. Diagnosis is usually based on the pattern of symptoms, response to therapy over time, and spirometry lung function testing. Asthma is classified according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in one second, and peak expiratory flow rate.

Asthma is a long-term disease that inflames and narrows the airways in the lungs. The symptoms, which can vary from person to person, include wheezes, coughing, chest discomfort, and difficulty breathing. These symptoms might worsen with exercise or at night. The cause of asthma is a complex interaction of both genetic and environmental factors like exposure to air pollution and allergens. Some medications like aspirin and beta blockers also act as triggers. Diagnosis of asthma relies on symptoms, the response to therapy over periods of time, and lung function testing through spirometry. The classification of asthma is based on symptom frequency, forced expiratory volume in a second, and peak expiratory flow rate.
What is hay fever?

Hay fever can worsen symptoms of asthma, such as coughing and wheezing. Sinusitis. Prolonged sinus congestion due to hay fever may increase your risk of getting sinusitis \u2014 an infection or inflammation of the membrane that lines the sinuses. Ear infection. In children, hay fever often is a factor in middle ear infection (otitis media). Prevention

Hay fever is a condition that can worsen symptoms of asthma, such as coughing and wheezing. It leads to prolonged sinus congestion which may increase your risk of getting sinusitis, an infection or inflammation of the membrane lining the sinuses. In children, hay fever is often a contributing factor to middle ear infection, also known as otitis media.
What is urticaria?

Urticaria, or hives, are red, itchy welts that can appear on the skin, sometimes accompanied by swelling. Hives can be caused by an allergic reaction, but some hives can also be caused by other factors, such as viral infection, emotional stress, or autoimmune disorder. Learn how to diagnose, treat, and prevent hives from this article.

Urticaria, also known as hives, are red, itchy welts that may appear on the skin and can be accompanied by swelling. These can be caused by allergic reactions, viral infections, emotional stress, or autoimmune disorders.
What is anaphylaxis?

Anaphylaxis is a serious, potentially fatal allergic reaction and medical emergency that is rapid in onset and requires immediate medical attention regardless of use of emergency medication on site. It typically causes more than one of the following: an itchy rash, throat closing due to swelling that can obstruct or stop breathing; severe tongue swelling that can also interfere with or stop breathing; shortness of breath, vomiting, lightheadedness, loss of consciousness, low blood pressure, and medical shock. These symptoms typically start in minutes to hours and then increase very rapidly to life-threatening levels. Urgent medical treatment is required to prevent serious harm and death, even if the patient has used an epipen or has taken other medications in response, and even if symptoms appear to be improving.

Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially fatal allergic reaction. It occurs rapidly and requires immediate medical attention. Symptoms can include an itchy rash, throat or tongue swelling that can obstruct breathing, shortness of breath, vomiting, lightheadedness, loss of consciousness, low blood pressure, and medical shock. These symptoms start in minutes to hours and can rapidly escalate to life-threatening levels. Urgent treatment is needed to prevent severe harm or death, even if initial symptoms seem to be improving or if the patient has used emergency medication like an epipen.
What is allergy testing?

Allergy testing can help confirm or rule out allergies and consequently reduce adverse reactions and limit unnecessary avoidance and medications. Correct allergy diagnosis, counseling and avoidance advice based on valid allergy test results is of utmost importance and can help reduce the incidence of symptoms, and the need for medications and improve quality of life. A healthcare provider can use the test results to identify the specific allergic triggers that may be contributing to the symptoms. Using this information, along with a physical examination and case history, the doctor can diagnose the cause of the symptoms and tailor treatments that will help the patient feel better. A negative result can help the doctor rule out allergies in order to consider other possibilities. Ruling out allergies is as important as confirming them to limit unnecessary avoidance, worry and negative social impact.

Allergy testing is a method used to help confirm or disprove suspicions of specific allergens the patient may be sensitive to. Through this testing, healthcare providers can identify specific allergic triggers causing symptoms to the patient. The results, when combined with a physical examination and case history, can allow the doctor to diagnose the cause of the symptoms and customize treatments. A negative result is also valuable as it can help rule out allergies, allowing consideration of other possibilities. This can prevent unnecessary avoidance of certain substances and reduce unnecessary worry.
What is allergy treatment?

Treatment. Allergy treatments include: Allergen avoidance. Your provider will help you take steps to identify and avoid your allergy triggers. This is generally the most important step in preventing allergic reactions and reducing symptoms. Medications. Depending on your allergy, medications can help reduce your immune system reaction and ease ...

Allergy treatment generally includes allergen avoidance, which means identifying and avoiding the triggers of your allergies. This is usually the most essential step to prevent allergic reactions and reduce symptoms. Depending on the type of allergy, medications are also used to help decrease the immune system's reaction and alleviate symptoms.
What is desensitization?
DESENSITIZATION meaning: 1. the process of causing someone to experience something, usually an emotion or a pain, less\u2026. Learn more.
Desensitization refers to the process of causing someone to experience something, usually an emotion or a pain, less intensely.
What is hyposensitization?

Allergen immunotherapy, also known as desensitization or hypo-sensitization, is a medical treatment for environmental allergies, such as insect bites, and asthma. [1] [2] Immunotherapy involves exposing people to larger and larger amounts of allergens in an attempt to change the immune system's response. [1]

Hyposensitization, also known as allergen immunotherapy or desensitization, is a medical treatment for environmental allergies and asthma. It involves exposing people to larger and larger amounts of allergens in an attempt to change the immune system's response.
What is allograft?

allograft, in medical procedures, the transfer of tissue between genetically nonidentical members of the same species, although of a compatible blood type. Allografts are commonly used in the transplants of skin, corneas, hearts, livers, kidneys, and bone and bone marrow, although transplants of the last often come from relatives.

An allograft is a medical procedure involving the transfer of tissue between non-genetically identical members of the same species who have a compatible blood type. It is commonly used in transplants of skin, corneas, hearts, livers, kidneys, and bone and bone marrow. However, transplants for bone and bone marrow often come from relatives.
What is autograft?

Autotransplantation is the transplantation of organs, tissues, or even particular proteins from one part of the body to another in the same person. The autologous tissue transplanted by such a procedure is called an autograft or autotransplant. It is contrasted with allotransplantation, syngeneic transplantation and xenotransplantation. A common example is the removal of a piece of bone and its being ground into a paste for the reconstruction of another portion of bone. Autotransplantation, although most common with blood, bone, or skin, can be used for a wide variety of organs. One of the rare examples is autotransplantation of a kidney from one side of the body to the other. Kidney autotransplantation is used as a treatment for nutcracker syndrome.

Autograft, also known as autotransplantation, refers to the transplantation of organs, tissues, or proteins from one part of the body to another in the same person. Common examples include blood, bone or skin transplantations. It can also be used for a variety of organs. A rare example is the autotransplantation of a kidney from one side of the body to the other, often used as a treatment for nutcracker syndrome.
What is xenograft?

Xenotransplantation, or heterologous transplant, is the transplantation of living cells, tissues or organs from one species to another. Such cells, tissues or organs are called xenografts or xenotransplants. It is contrasted with allotransplantation, syngeneic transplantation or isotransplantation and autotransplantation. Xenotransplantation is an artificial method of creating an animal-human chimera, that is, a human with a subset of animal cells. In contrast, an individual where each cell contains genetic material from a human and an animal is called a human\u2013animal hybrid. Patient derived xenografts are created by xenotransplantation of human tumor cells into immunocompromised mice, and is a research technique frequently used in pre-clinical oncology research. Human xenotransplantation offers a potential treatment for end-stage organ failure, a significant health problem in parts of the industrialized world. It also raises many novel medical, legal and ethical issues.

Xenograft, also known as heterologous transplant, is the transplantation of living cells, tissues, or organs from one species to another. It's an artificial method used to generate an animal-human chimera, a human having a subset of animal cells. This practice is often contrasted with allotransplantation, syngeneic transplantation, or autotransplantation. In the field of oncology research, patient-derived xenografts are frequently created by transplanting human tumor cells into immunocompromised mice. Xenotransplantation could potentially be a treatment for end-stage organ failure, but it also introduces new medical, legal, and ethical issues.
What is cell antigen?

An antigen is a marker that tells your immune system whether something in your body is harmful or not. Antigens are found on viruses, bacteria, tumors and normal cells of your body. Antigen testing is done to diagnose viral infections, monitor and screen for certain conditions and determine whether a donor is a good match for a transplant.

A cell antigen is a marker found on cells, including viruses, bacteria, tumors, and normal cells, that helps your immune system to identify whether something in your body is harmful or not. Antigen testing is often used to diagnose viral infections, to monitor and screen for various conditions, and to determine if a donor is a good match for a transplant.
What is tissue antigen?

An antigen is a marker that tells your immune system whether something in your body is harmful or not. Antigens are found on viruses, bacteria, tumors and normal cells of your body. Antigen testing is done to diagnose viral infections, monitor and screen for certain conditions and determine whether a donor is a good match for a transplant.

A tissue antigen is a marker found on cells, including those of tissues, that helps your immune system to distinguish between its own cells and foreign, potentially harmful invaders. Antigens are found on a variety of entities such as viruses, bacteria, and tumors, but also on normal cells in your body. They are significant in diagnosing viral infections, monitoring for certain conditions, and determining compatibility in organ transplants.
What is organ antigen?

An antigen is a marker that tells your immune system whether something in your body is harmful or not. Antigens are found on viruses, bacteria, tumors and normal cells of your body. Antigen testing is done to diagnose viral infections, monitor and screen for certain conditions and determine whether a donor is a good match for a transplant.

An organ antigen is a marker found on normal cells of an organ, bacteria, tumors or viruses. These markers help your immune system distinguish between harmful and harmless entities in your body. In the context of organ transplants, antigen testing is crucial to determine if a donor is a suitable match for a recipient.
What are immunochemical techniques?

Immunochemical techniques are methods used in clinical laboratories to detect diseases, infections, or presence of specific substances like therapeutic or illicit drugs in a patient's bodily fluids like blood, serum, plasma, urine, or saliva. An example of this is immunostaining, a technique that when combined with fluorescent labels, allows for the detection of these specific substances.
What are immunological techniques?
Immunological techniques include both experimental methods to study the immune system and methods to generate or use immunological reagents as experimental tools. The most common immunological ...
Immunological techniques are experimental methods used to study the immune system, as well as methods to create or use immunological reagents as experimental tools.
What is serological techniques?

serological test, any of several laboratory procedures carried out on a sample of blood serum (the clear liquid that separates from the blood when it is allowed to clot) for the purpose of detecting antibodies or antibody-like substances that appear specifically in association with certain diseases. There are different types of serological tests\u2014for example, flocculation tests ...

Serological techniques are laboratory procedures carried out on a sample of blood serum, which is the clear liquid that separates from the blood when it is allowed to clot. These techniques are used to detect antibodies or antibody-like substances that appear specifically in association with certain diseases. There are different types of serological tests, such as flocculation tests, among others.
What is T cell receptor?

The T-cell receptor is a protein complex found on the surface of T cells, or T lymphocytes, that is responsible for recognizing fragments of antigen as peptides bound to major histocompatibility complex molecules. The binding between TCR and antigen peptides is of relatively low affinity and is degenerate: that is, many TCRs recognize the same antigen peptide and many antigen peptides are recognized by the same TCR. The TCR is composed of two different protein chains. In humans, in 95% of T cells the TCR consists of an alpha chain and a beta chain, whereas in 5% of T cells the TCR consists of gamma and delta chains. This ratio changes during ontogeny and in diseased states. It also differs between species. Orthologues of the 4 loci have been mapped in various species. Each locus can produce a variety of polypeptides with constant and variable regions.

The T-cell receptor is a protein complex located on the surface of T cells or T lymphocytes. Its function is to recognize fragments of antigen as peptides that are bound to major histocompatibility complex molecules. Each T-cell receptor can recognize many antigen peptides, and many antigen peptides can be recognized by the same receptor. The T-cell receptor is composed of two protein chains: an alpha chain and a beta chain in 95% of T cells, and a gamma and delta chains in the remaining 5%. Changes in these ratios can occur during development and in states of disease.
What is B cell receptor?

The B-cell receptor is a transmembrane protein on the surface of a B cell. A B-cell receptor is composed of a membrane-bound immunoglobulin molecule and a signal transduction moiety. The former forms a type 1 transmembrane receptor protein, and is typically located on the outer surface of these lymphocyte cells. Through biochemical signaling and by physically acquiring antigens from the immune synapses, the BCR controls the activation of the B cell. B cells are able to gather and grab antigens by engaging biochemical modules for receptor clustering, cell spreading, generation of pulling forces, and receptor transport, which eventually culminates in endocytosis and antigen presentation. B cells' mechanical activity adheres to a pattern of negative and positive feedbacks that regulate the quantity of removed antigen by manipulating the dynamic of BCR\u2013antigen bonds directly.

The B-cell receptor (BCR) is a membrane-bound protein found on the surface of B cells. It is composed of two main parts: a transmembrane immunoglobulin molecule and a signal transduction moiety. The BCR is involved in the activation of the B cell, and it does this through biochemical signaling and by physically acquiring antigens. B cells can gather and grab antigens due to the BCR controlling their function and activities. This leads to endocytosis, where the cell engulfs the antigen, and antigen presentation, where the cell shows the antigen to other cells in the immune system. B cells' activity is regulated by feedback mechanisms that control the amount of antigen captured and interact with the BCR and antigen bonds.
What is antibody diversity?

Even in the absence of antigen stimulation, a human can probably make more than 1012 different antibody molecules\u2014its preimmune antibody repertoire. Moreover, the antigen-binding sites of many antibodies can cross-react with a variety of related but different antigenic determinants, making the antibody defense force even more formidable. The preimmune repertoire is apparently large enough to ...

Antibody diversity refers to the ability of the human immune system to produce a vast range of different antibodies, even without stimulation by an antigen. This preimmune antibody repertoire can probably generate over a trillion different antibody molecules. These antibodies can also cross-react to various related but distinct antigenic determinants, providing a robust defense mechanism for the body.
What is cell proliferation in immunology?

Cell division, growth, and proliferation. Cell proliferation is the process by which a cell grows and divides to produce two daughter cells. Cell proliferation leads to an exponential increase in cell number and is therefore a rapid mechanism of tissue growth. Cell ...
Cell proliferation in immunology refers to the process whereby a cell grows and divides to produce two daughter cells. This leads to a rapid increase in cell number, facilitating swift tissue growth.
What is cell differentiation in immunology?

Cell Differentiation Definition. Cellular differentiation, or simply cell differentiation, is the process through which a cell undergoes changes in gene expression to become a more specific type of cell. The process of cell differentiation allows multi-cellular organisms to create uniquely functional cell types and body plans.

Cell differentiation in immunology refers to the process where a cell undergoes changes in gene expression to become a more specific type of cell. This process allows multi-cellular organisms to create uniquely functional cell types and body plans, which is crucial for functioning immunity.
What is cell maturation in immunology?

How cells become specialized, or \"mature,\" is important for cell and developmental biology. While maturity is usually deemed a terminal fate, it may be more helpful to consider maturation not as a switch but as a dynamic continuum of adaptive phenotypic states set by genetic and environment programing. The hallmarks of maturity comprise ...

Cell maturation in immunology is the process by which cells become specialized. It's a dynamic continuum of adaptive phenotypic states set by genetic and environmental programming. While commonly considered as a final stage, maturation should rather be seen as a sequence of adaptive states that prepare the cell for its specific function in the organism's defense mechanism.
What is cell migration in immunology?

Cell migration in immunology is a key process where immune cells move towards sites of inflammation due to tissue damage or infection, typically induced by the release of cytokines and other inflammatory signals.
What is cell death in immunology?

INTRODUCTION. Cell death is a physiological event essential for homeostasis in multicellular organisms. However, it is also implicated in multiple pathological conditions such as neurodegenerative and ischaemic disorders, cancer, and autoinflammatory and autoimmune diseases [1, 2, 3].Consequently, cell death is tightly regulated by a strict biochemical programme, which depends on regulatory ...

Cell death in immunology is a physiological event that is essential for maintaining balance in multicellular organisms. It is regulated by a strict biochemical programme and is involved in various pathological conditions such as neurodegenerative and ischaemic disorders, cancer, autoinflammatory and autoimmune diseases.
What is lymph node?

A lymph node, or lymph gland, is a kidney-shaped organ of the lymphatic system and the adaptive immune system. A large number of lymph nodes are linked throughout the body by the lymphatic vessels. They are major sites of lymphocytes that include B and T cells. Lymph nodes are important for the proper functioning of the immune system, acting as filters for foreign particles including cancer cells, but have no detoxification function. In the lymphatic system, a lymph node is a secondary lymphoid organ. A lymph node is enclosed in a fibrous capsule and is made up of an outer cortex and an inner medulla. Lymph nodes become inflamed or enlarged in various diseases, which may range from trivial throat infections to life-threatening cancers. The condition of lymph nodes is very important in cancer staging, which decides the treatment to be used and determines the prognosis. Lymphadenopathy refers to glands that are enlarged or swollen.

A lymph node, or lymph gland, is a kidney-shaped organ that forms part of the lymphatic system and the adaptive immune system. It's linked throughout the body by lymphatic vessels. Lymph nodes are significant since they serve as filters for foreign particles including cancer cells, and are home to lymphocytes which include B and T cells. While they play a crucial role in the immune system, they have no detoxification function. In cases of disease, which can be as minor as a throat infection or as severe as cancer, lymph nodes can become inflamed or enlarged. They are vital for determining the course of treatment and the prognosis in cancer staging. Lymphadenopathy is the term used when glands are enlarged or swollen.
What is spleen?

The spleen is an organ found in almost all vertebrates. Similar in structure to a large lymph node, it acts primarily as a blood filter. The word spleen comes from Ancient Greek \u03c3\u03c0\u03bb\u03ae\u03bd. The spleen plays very important roles in regard to red blood cells and the immune system. It removes old red blood cells and holds a reserve of blood, which can be valuable in case of hemorrhagic shock, and also recycles iron. As a part of the mononuclear phagocyte system, it metabolizes hemoglobin removed from senescent red blood cells. The globin portion of hemoglobin is degraded to its constitutive amino acids, and the heme portion is metabolized to bilirubin, which is removed in the liver. The spleen houses antibody-producing lymphocytes in its white pulp and monocytes which remove antibody-coated bacteria and antibody-coated blood cells by way of blood and lymph node circulation. These monocytes, upon moving to injured tissue, turn into dendritic cells and macrophages while promoting tissue healing.

The spleen is an organ found in almost all vertebrates. It functions primarily as a blood filter, removing old red blood cells, holding a reserve of blood, and recycling iron. It is also involved in the immune system, housing antibody-producing lymphocytes and monocytes that remove bacteria and blood cells from the blood and lymph node circulation. When these monocytes move to injured tissue, they turn into dendritic cells and macrophages to promote tissue healing.
What is thymus?

The thymus is a specialized primary lymphoid organ of the immune system. Within the thymus, thymus cell lymphocytes or T cells mature. T cells are critical to the adaptive immune system, where the body adapts to specific foreign invaders. The thymus is located in the upper front part of the chest, in the anterior superior mediastinum, behind the sternum, and in front of the heart. It is made up of two lobes, each consisting of a central medulla and an outer cortex, surrounded by a capsule. The thymus is made up of immature T cells called thymocytes, as well as lining cells called epithelial cells which help the thymocytes develop. T cells that successfully develop react appropriately with MHC immune receptors of the body and not against proteins of the body. The thymus is largest and most active during the neonatal and pre-adolescent periods. By the early teens, the thymus begins to decrease in size and activity and the tissue of the thymus is gradually replaced by fatty tissue.

The thymus is a specialized primary organ of the immune system. Its main role is the maturation of T cells, which are critical to the adaptive immune system that helps the body adapt to foreign invaders. The thymus is situated in the upper front part of the chest, behind the sternum, and in front of the heart. It is composed of two lobes, each consisting of a central medulla and an outer cortex. The thymus is most active during the neonatal and pre-adolescent periods, after which it begins to decrease in size and activity, with its tissue gradually replaced by fatty tissue.
What is tonsil?

The tonsils are a set of lymphoid organs facing into the aerodigestive tract, which is known as Waldeyer's tonsillar ring and consists of the adenoid tonsil, two tubal tonsils, two palatine tonsils, and the lingual tonsils. These organs play an important role in the immune system. When used unqualified, the term most commonly refers specifically to the palatine tonsils, which are two lymphoid organs situated at either side of the back of the human throat. The palatine tonsils and the adenoid tonsil are organs consisting of lymphoepithelial tissue located near the oropharynx and nasopharynx.

Tonsils are sets of lymphoid organs facing into the aerodigestive tract, forming what's known as Waldeyer's tonsillar ring. They consist of the adenoid tonsil, two tubal tonsils, two palatine tonsils, and the lingual tonsils. These organs have an important role in the immune system. However, when simply referred to as 'tonsils', it usually pertains specifically to the palatine tonsils. These are two lymphoid organs located on each side at the back of the human throat. The palatine tonsils and the adenoid tonsil are made up of lymphoepithelial tissue and are situated near the oropharynx and nasopharynx.
What is appendix?
The appendix is a finger-like tube in the lower right part of the abdomen. Appendicitis occurs when the appendix becomes inflamed. Its role has long been a mystery, but some experts believe they ...

The appendix is a finger-like tube located in the lower right part of the abdomen. Its function has long been a subject of debate among medical experts, some of whom believe it plays a certain role in the human body. The condition known as appendicitis occurs when the appendix gets inflamed.
What is bone marrow?

Bone marrow is a semi-solid tissue found within the spongy portions of bones. In birds and mammals, bone marrow is the primary site of new blood cell production. It is composed of hematopoietic cells, marrow adipose tissue, and supportive stromal cells. In adult humans, bone marrow is primarily located in the ribs, vertebrae, sternum, and bones of the pelvis. Bone marrow comprises approximately 5% of total body mass in healthy adult humans, such that a man weighing 73 kg will have around 3.7 kg of bone marrow. Human marrow produces approximately 500 billion blood cells per day, which join the systemic circulation via permeable vasculature sinusoids within the medullary cavity. All types of hematopoietic cells, including both myeloid and lymphoid lineages, are created in bone marrow; however, lymphoid cells must migrate to other lymphoid organs in order to complete maturation.

Bone marrow is a semi-solid tissue found within the spongy parts of bones. In humans and other mammals, it is the primary location where new blood cells are produced. It is made up of hematopoietic cells, marrow adipose tissue, and supportive stromal cells. Bone marrow is majorly found in the ribs, vertebrae, sternum, and bones of the pelvis in adults. It makes up about 5% of the total body mass in healthy adults, meaning a person weighing 73 kg will have around 3.7 kg of bone marrow. It produces approximately 500 billion blood cells each day that enter the overall body's circulation. All types of hematopoietic cells, including both myeloid and lymphoid lineages, are created in bone marrow. However, lymphoid cells need to migrate to other lymphoid organs to finish maturation.
What is immune response?

An immune response is a physiological reaction which occurs within an organism in the context of inflammation for the purpose of defending against exogenous factors. These include a wide variety of different toxins, viruses, intra- and extracellular bacteria, protozoa, helminths, and fungi which could cause serious problems to the health of the host organism if not cleared from the body. In addition, there are other forms of immune response. For example, harmless exogenous factors can trigger allergy; latex and metals are also known allergens. A transplanted tissue or organ can cause graft-versus-host disease. A type of immune reactivity known as Rh disease can be observed in pregnant women. These special forms of immune response are classified as hypersensitivity. Another special form of immune response is antitumor immunity. In general, there are two branches of the immune response, the innate and the adaptive, which work together to protect against pathogens.

The immune response is a physiological reaction that occurs within an organism for the purpose of defending against external offensive elements such as bacteria, viruses, toxins, etc. It can also get triggered by harmless factors leading to allergies or cause diseases like graft-versus-host disease and Rh disease in pregnant women, termed as hypersensitivity. In addition, there's a special form of immune response, antitumor immunity. There are two branches of the immune response, the innate and the adaptive, which collaborate to protect against pathogens.
What is immune activation?

The adaptive (active) immune response takes 1 to 2 weeks to reach its full functioning capacity, much longer compared to the twelve hours required to activate the innate immunity completely. With the development of the adaptive immune response, comes a phenomenon called immunologic memory, an immune defense that can last a lifetime to provide ...

Immune activation refers to the process where the adaptive (active) immune response is triggered. This response takes 1 to 2 weeks to fully develop, which allows the body to combat specific pathogens or diseases more effectively. An important aspect of this process is 'immunologic memory', which can last a lifetime and provides a quicker and more efficient response to previously encountered pathogens.
What is immune suppression?

Immunosuppression is a reduction of the activation or efficacy of the immune system. Some portions of the immune system itself have immunosuppressive effects on other parts of the immune system, and immunosuppression may occur as an adverse reaction to treatment of other conditions. In general, deliberately induced immunosuppression is performed to prevent the body from rejecting an organ transplant. Additionally, it is used for treating graft-versus-host disease after a bone marrow transplant, or for the treatment of auto-immune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, Sj\u00f6gren's syndrome, or Crohn's disease. This is typically done using medications, but may involve surgery, plasmapheresis, or radiation. A person who is undergoing immunosuppression, or whose immune system is weak for some other reasons, is said to be immunocompromised.

Immune suppression, or immunosuppression, refers to the reduction of the activation or effectiveness of the immune system. It is deliberately induced to prevent the body from rejecting an organ transplant, to treat graft-versus-host disease following a bone marrow transplant, or for the treatment of autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, Sj\u00f6gren's syndrome, and Crohn's disease. It can be achieved through medications, surgery, plasmapheresis, or radiation. When a person is undergoing immunosuppression or their immune system is otherwise weakened, they are described as being immunocompromised.
What is immune memory?

In biology, immunity is the state of being insusceptible or resistant to a noxious agent or process, especially a pathogen or infectious disease. Immunity may occur naturally or be produced by prior exposure or immunization.

Immune memory is a biological function where the immune system remembers previous encounters with specific pathogens. This memory enables your immune system to react quickly and efficiently to subsequent encounters with the same pathogen. It's the principle upon which immunizations work: giving a small, safe piece of the pathogen to 'teach' the immune system how to fight it off in the future.
What is immune tolerance?

Immune tolerance, also known as immunological tolerance or immunotolerance, refers to the immune system's state of unresponsiveness to substances or tissues that would otherwise trigger an immune response. It arises from prior exposure to a specific antigen and contrasts the immune system's conventional role in eliminating foreign antigens. Depending on the site of induction, tolerance is categorized as either central tolerance, occurring in the thymus and bone marrow, or peripheral tolerance, taking place in other tissues and lymph nodes. Although the mechanisms establishing central and peripheral tolerance differ, their outcomes are analogous, ensuring immune system modulation. Immune tolerance is important for normal physiology and homeostasis. Central tolerance is crucial for enabling the immune system to differentiate between self and non-self antigens, thereby preventing autoimmunity.

Immune tolerance, also known as immunological tolerance, is the state of the immune system in which it does not react to substances or tissues that would ordinarily trigger an immune response. This condition happens due to previous exposure to a specific antigen. It is important for normal physiology and homeostasis. The tolerance can be categorized as central and peripheral, where central tolerance is vital for the immune system to differentiate between self and non-self antigens and therefore prevent autoimmunity.
What is non-specific immunity?
What is non-specific immunity? The non-specific immunity definition is the immunity you are born with that provides generalized protection against pathogens. This generalized defense system works ...
Non-specific immunity, also known as innate immunity, is the generalized defense system that you are born with. It provides a broad protection against pathogens.
What is specific immunity?
Specific immunity, also known as acquired immunity, is developed after the body is exposed to specific pathogens as a form of future protection. It is the body's way of remembering what dangers ...

Specific immunity, also known as acquired immunity, is developed when the body is exposed to certain pathogens and develops a form of protection against those specific pathogens in the future. It's the body's method of 'remembering' what dangers it has encountered previously and preemptively preparing defenses for them.
What is natural immunity?
Natural immunity is a subtype of active immunity. Here's what you need to know about how it's acquired and how it protects you.
Natural immunity is a subtype of active immunity. It is acquired and provides protection to your body.
What is acquired immunity?

Acquired immunity helps your immune system get stronger. And the stronger your immune system is, the less likely you are to get sick. When your immune system is exposed to a pathogen, it learns to ...

Acquired immunity refers to the immunity that your body develops over time as it is exposed to different pathogens. This exposure helps your immune system to strengthen, thus reducing the likelihood of becoming ill from the same pathogen in the future.
What is active immunity?

Active immunity is a resistance to disease through the creation of antibodies by the immune system. As opposed to passive immunity, where antibodies are injected into an organism during pregnancy or artificially, active immunity requires a process of training immune cells to recognize and counteract foreign bodies.

Active immunity is a type of resistance to disease that is achieved through the creation of antibodies by the immune system. This immunity requires a process where immune cells are trained to recognize and counter foreign bodies. This is different from passive immunity, which is where antibodies are injected into an organism, either during pregnancy or artificially.
What is passive immunity?

In immunology, passive immunity is the transfer of active humoral immunity of ready-made antibodies. Passive immunity can occur naturally, when maternal antibodies are transferred to the fetus through the placenta, and it can also be induced artificially, when high levels of antibodies specific to a pathogen or toxin are transferred to non-immune persons through blood products that contain antibodies, such as in immunoglobulin therapy or antiserum therapy. Passive immunization is used when there is a high risk of infection and insufficient time for the body to develop its own immune response, or to reduce the symptoms of ongoing or immunosuppressive diseases. Passive immunization can be provided when people cannot synthesize antibodies, and when they have been exposed to a disease that they do not have immunity against.

Passive immunity is the transfer of active humoral immunity in the form of ready-made antibodies. This can occur naturally, as in the case of maternal antibodies being transferred to the fetus through the placenta. It can also be induced artificially through immunoglobulin therapy or antiserum therapy where high levels of antibodies specific to a pathogen or toxin are transferred to people who are non-immune. This is used when there is a high risk of infection and insufficient time for the body to develop its own immune response, or to decrease the symptoms of ongoing or immunosuppressive diseases. It is also useful when individuals cannot synthesize antibodies or have been exposed to a disease against which they have no immunity.
What is clinical immunology?

Clinical immunology. Clinical immunology is the study of diseases caused by disorders of the immune system (failure, aberrant action, and malignant growth of the cellular elements of the system). It also involves diseases of other systems, where immune reactions play a part in the pathology and clinical features.

Clinical immunology is the study of diseases that occur due to disorders of the immune system. It covers diseases resulting from failure, aberrant action, or malignant growth of the cellular elements of the immune system. Clinical immunology also deals with diseases of other systems where immune reactions contribute to the pathology and clinical features.
What is immunodiagnostics?

An immunoassay is a biochemical test that measures the presence or concentration of a macromolecule or a small molecule in a solution through the use of an antibody or an antigen. The molecule detected by the immunoassay is often referred to as an \"analyte\" and is in many cases a protein, although it may be other kinds of molecules, of different sizes and types, as long as the proper antibodies that have the required properties for the assay are developed. Analytes in biological liquids such as serum or urine are frequently measured using immunoassays for medical and research purposes. Immunoassays come in many different formats and variations. Immunoassays may be run in multiple steps with reagents being added and washed away or separated at different points in the assay. Multi-step assays are often called separation immunoassays or heterogeneous immunoassays. Some immunoassays can be carried out simply by mixing the reagents and samples and making a physical measurement.

Immunodiagnostics is a type of biochemical test that measures the presence or concentration of a molecule (often a protein) in a solution by using an antibody or an antigen. This molecule is commonly referred to as an 'analyte'. Analytes, usually found in biological liquids like serum or urine, are often measured for medical and research purposes using immunoassays. The process comes in several formats and can involve various steps where reagents are added, washed away, or separated at different points in the assay. Some immunoassays can be performed by just mixing the reagents and samples and making a physical measurement.
What is immunotherapy?

Immunotherapy or biological therapy is the treatment of disease by activating or suppressing the immune system. Immunotherapies designed to elicit or amplify an immune response are classified as activation immunotherapies, while immunotherapies that reduce or suppress are classified as suppression immunotherapies. Immunotherapy is under preliminary research for its potential to treat various forms of cancer. Cell-based immunotherapies are effective for some cancers. Immune effector cells such as lymphocytes, macrophages, dendritic cells, natural killer cells, and cytotoxic T lymphocytes work together to defend the body against cancer by targeting abnormal antigens expressed on the surface of tumor cells. Vaccine-induced immunity to COVID-19 relies mostly on an immunomodulatory T-cell response. Therapies such as granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, interferons, imiquimod and cellular membrane fractions from bacteria are licensed for medical use.

Immunotherapy, also known as biological therapy, activates or suppresses the immune system to treat diseases. If the aim is to elicit or amplify an immune response, it's known as an activation immunotherapy, while those that reduce or suppress an immune response are classified as suppression immunotherapies. It's being researched for its potential in treating various cancers and relies on immune effector cells such as lymphocytes, macrophages, dendritic cells, etc. to defend the body by targeting abnormal antigens on tumor cells. Some immunotherapies like granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, interferons, and imiquimod are already licensed for medical use. Immunotherapy has also played a key role in vaccine-induced immunity against COVID-19, primarily through an immunomodulatory T-cell response.
What is allergy?

Allergies, also known as allergic diseases, are various conditions caused by hypersensitivity of the immune system to typically harmless substances in the environment. These diseases include hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis. Symptoms may include red eyes, an itchy rash, sneezing, coughing, a runny nose, shortness of breath, or swelling. Note that food intolerances and food poisoning are separate conditions. Common allergens include pollen and certain foods. Metals and other substances may also cause such problems. Food, insect stings, and medications are common causes of severe reactions. Their development is due to both genetic and environmental factors. The underlying mechanism involves immunoglobulin E antibodies, part of the body's immune system, binding to an allergen and then to a receptor on mast cells or basophils where it triggers the release of inflammatory chemicals such as histamine.

Allergies are conditions caused by hypersensitivity of the immune system to generally harmless substances in the environment. Examples of these diseases include hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis. Symptoms can vary, including red eyes, itchy rash, sneezing, coughing, a runny nose, shortness of breath, and swelling. Common triggers include pollen, certain foods, metals, insect stings, and medications. Although disabilities can arise for both genetic and environmental reasons, the underlying mechanism involves immunoglobulin E antibodies, part of the body's immune system, triggering the release of inflammatory chemicals such as histamine upon contact with an allergen.
What is allergic reaction?
wheezing. fear or anxiety. heart palpitations. flushing of the face. swelling of the face, eyes, or tongue. dizziness or vertigo. weakness. unconsciousness. A severe and sudden allergic reaction ...

An allergic reaction is a sudden, severe response by the body's immune system to an exposure. Symptoms can include wheezing, fear or anxiety, heart palpitations, flushing of the face, swelling of the face, eyes, or tongue, dizziness or vertigo, weakness and even unconsciousness. If you experience these symptoms, you should seek immediate medical attention.
What is allergic disease?

Allergies, also known as allergic diseases, are various conditions caused by hypersensitivity of the immune system to typically harmless substances in the environment. These diseases include hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis. Symptoms may include red eyes, an itchy rash, sneezing, coughing, a runny nose, shortness of breath, or swelling. Note that food intolerances and food poisoning are separate conditions. Common allergens include pollen and certain foods. Metals and other substances may also cause such problems. Food, insect stings, and medications are common causes of severe reactions. Their development is due to both genetic and environmental factors. The underlying mechanism involves immunoglobulin E antibodies, part of the body's immune system, binding to an allergen and then to a receptor on mast cells or basophils where it triggers the release of inflammatory chemicals such as histamine.

Allergic diseases are conditions caused due to hypersensitivity of the immune system to usually harmless substances in the environment. These include diseases like hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis. Common symptoms can include red eyes, itchy rash, sneezing, coughing, running nose, shortness of breath, or swelling. Common allergens include substances like pollen and certain foods, as well as metals and other substances. It's important to note that food intolerances and food poisoning are separate conditions. The development of these diseases usually involves both genetic and environmental factors. The mechanism underlying these reactions often involves immunoglobulin E antibodies, part of the immune system, binding to an allergen and triggering the release of inflammatory chemicals like histamine.
What is molecular immunology?
Molecular Immunology is a peer reviewed academic journal published by Pergamon Press. The editor is M.R. Daha.
Molecular Immunology is a peer-reviewed academic journal published by Pergamon Press. It is edited by M.R. Daha.
What is cellular immunology?

The immune system consists of factors that provide innate and acquired immunity, and has evolved to become more specific, complex, efficient, and regulated. One of the principal functions of the human immune system is to defend against infecting and other foreign agents by distinguishing self from non-self (foreign antigens) and to marshal other protective responses from leukocytes.

Cellular immunology involves the aspect of the immune system that consists of innate and acquired immunity. This system has evolved to become more complex, specific, efficient, and well-regulated. Its main function is to protect the human body against infections and other foreign agents by distinguishing self from non-self (foreign antigens). This system also instigates other protective responses from leukocytes.
What is immunochemistry?

Immunochemistry is the study of the chemistry of the immune system. This involves the study of the properties, functions, interactions and production of the chemical components of the immune system, immune responses and determination of immune materials by immunochemical assays. In addition, immunochemistry is the study of the identities and functions of the components of the immune system. Immunochemistry is also used to describe the application of immune system components, in particular antibodies, to chemically labelled antigen molecules for visualization. Various methods in immunochemistry have been developed and refined, and used in scientific study, from virology to molecular evolution. Immunochemical techniques include: enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, immunoblotting, precipitation and agglutination reactions, immunoelectrophoresis, immunophenotyping, immunochromatographic assay and cyflometry.

Immunochemistry is a branch of science that studies the chemistry of the immune system. It involves examining the properties, functions, interactions, and production of the immune system's chemical components. The term 'immunochemistry' also describes the practice of using components of the immune system, specifically antibodies, to chemically labelled antigen molecules for visualization. This field has various techniques including enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, immunoblotting, precipitation and agglutination reactions, immunoelectrophoresis, immunophenotyping, immunochromatographic assay and cyflometry. These techniques are used in many scientific studies, from virology to molecular evolution.
What is immunopathology?

Immunopathology is a branch of medicine that deals with immune responses associated with disease. It includes the study of the pathology of an organism, organ system, or disease with respect to the immune system, immunity, and immune responses. In biology, it refers to damage caused to an organism by its own immune response, as a result of an infection. It could be due to mismatch between pathogen and host species, and often occurs when an animal pathogen infects a human.

Immunopathology is a branch of medicine that focuses on immune responses associated with disease. This field studies the pathology of an organism, organ system, or disease concerning the immune system, immunity, and immune responses. In the biological context, immunopathology refers to the damage an organism sustains from its own immune response, often as a result of an infection. This typically occurs when a pathogen meant for an animal infects a human, leading to a mismatch between the pathogen and host species.
What is immunoendocrinology?

Immunoendocrinology is a rapidly developing field of research that seeks to understand the intersection of the immune and endocrine systems. Immunoendocrinology: Scientific and Clinical Aspects explores in detail the current knowledge of immunoendocrinology, namely endocrine disorders produced by disorders of immune function.

Immunoendocrinology is a fast-growing field of research dedicated to studying the intersection of the immune and endocrine systems. It mainly deals with endocrine disorders that are produced by disorders of immune function.
What is immunogenetics?

Immunogenetics or immungenetics is the branch of Medical Immunology and Medical Genetics that explores the relationship between the immune system and genetics. Autoimmune diseases, such as type 1 diabetes, are complex genetic traits which result from defects in the immune system. Identification of genes defining the immune defects may identify new target genes for therapeutic approaches. Alternatively, genetic variations can also help to define the immunological pathway leading to disease.

Immunogenetics is a branch of Medical Immunology and Medical Genetics. It studies the relationship between genetics and the immune system. This field is particularly important when exploring autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes, which result from defects in the immune system. Genes defining these immune defects, potentially identified through studying immunogenetics, could help to create new therapeutic strategies. Additionally, understanding how genetic variations define the immunological pathways leading to disease can also be an important aspect of immunogenetics.
What is cancer immunology?

Cancer immunology is an interdisciplinary branch of biology and a sub-discipline of immunology that is concerned with understanding the role of the immune system in the progression and development of cancer; the most well known application is cancer immunotherapy, which utilises the immune system as a treatment for cancer. Cancer immunosurveillance and immunoediting are based on protection against development of tumors in animal systems and identification of targets for immune recognition of human cancer.

Cancer immunology is a branch of biology focused on understanding the role of the immune system in the progression and development of cancer. It explores how the immune system can be utilized as a treatment for cancer, this application is known as cancer immunotherapy. It also involves cancer immunosurveillance and immunoediting which are based on protecting against the development of tumors in animal systems and identifying targets for immune recognition of human cancer.
What is tumor immunology?

Cancer immunology is an interdisciplinary branch of biology and a sub-discipline of immunology that is concerned with understanding the role of the immune system in the progression and development of cancer; the most well known application is cancer immunotherapy, which utilises the immune system as a treatment for cancer. Cancer immunosurveillance and immunoediting are based on protection against development of tumors in animal systems and identification of targets for immune recognition of human cancer.

Tumor immunology, also known as cancer immunology, is a branch of biology that focuses on understanding the role of the immune system in the progression and development of cancer. It is a sub-discipline of immunology. The main application of this field is cancer immunotherapy, which uses the immune system as a treatment for cancer. It also involves studying concepts like cancer immunosurveillance and immunoediting, which are about protection against the development of tumors in animal systems and identifying targets for immune recognition of human cancer.
What is immune deficiency?

Immunodeficiency, also known as immunocompromisation, is a state in which the immune system's ability to fight infectious diseases and cancer is compromised or entirely absent. Most cases are acquired due to extrinsic factors that affect the patient's immune system. Examples of these extrinsic factors include HIV infection and environmental factors, such as nutrition. Immunocompromisation may also be due to genetic diseases/flaws such as SCID. In clinical settings, immunosuppression by some drugs, such as steroids, can either be an adverse effect or the intended purpose of the treatment. Examples of such use is in organ transplant surgery as an anti-rejection measure and in patients with an overactive immune system, as in autoimmune diseases. Some people are born with intrinsic defects in their immune system, or primary immunodeficiency. A person who has an immunodeficiency of any kind is said to be immunocompromised.

Immune deficiency, also known as immunodeficiency, occurs when the immune system's ability to fight off infectious diseases and cancer is compromised or entirely absent. This state can be induced due to various extrinsic factors such as HIV infection, environmental factors including diet, or therapeutic drugs used for organ transplant surgery or autoimmune diseases. There are also cases where people are born with defects in their immune system, a condition known as primary immunodeficiency. In any case, individuals with immune deficiencies are referred to as immunocompromised.
What is immunosurveillance?

Cancer immunosurveillance is a process by which an organism's immune system recognizes transformed cells in order to inhibit the growth of neoplastic tissue. It comprises the first phase of immunoediting and is also known as the elimination phase.

Immunosurveillance is a process where the immune system identifies and destroys potential cancerous cells, thus inhibiting the growth of cancerous or neoplastic tissue. This is the first phase of immunoediting, also known as the elimination phase.
What is immunoregulation?

Immunoregulation. The immunoregulation has been shown to induce Tregs, and also T-cell apoptosis and anergy in a pathway involving GCN2 kinase, which is a stress-response kinase that is activated by elevations in uncharged tRNA [149-151]. From: Immune Biology of Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation, 2013.

Immunoregulation refers to a process that induces regulatory T cells (Tregs) and also activates T-cell apoptosis and anergy. This process involves the GCN2 kinase, a stress-response kinase that activates when there are increases in uncharged tRNA. It plays a critical role in the immune biology of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
What is immunoconjugate?

Immunoconjugates are antibodies conjugated to a second molecule, usually a toxin, radioisotope or label. These conjugates are used in immunotherapy and to develop monoclonal antibody therapy as a targeted form of chemotherapy when they are often known as antibody-drug conjugates. When the conjugates include a radioisotope see radioimmunotherapy. When the conjugates include a toxin see immunotoxin.

Immunoconjugates are antibodies that are connected to a second molecule, which could be a toxin, a radioisotope or a label. They are mainly used in immunotherapy and in the development of a specific form of chemotherapy known as monoclonal antibody therapy. Based on what the conjugates contain, they could be referred to as antibody-drug conjugates, radioimmunotherapies or immunotoxins.
What is immunosuppressant?
Immunosuppressive drugs, also known as immunosuppressive agents, immunosuppressants and antirejection medications, are drugs that inhibit or prevent the activity of the immune system.
Immunosuppressive drugs, also known as immunosuppressive agents, immunosuppressants and antirejection medications, are drugs that inhibit or prevent the activity of the immune system.
What is immunotoxicology?

Immunotoxicology is the study of the toxicity of foreign substances called xenobiotics and their effects on the immune system. Some toxic agents that are known to alter the immune system include: industrial chemicals, heavy metals, agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, drugs, ultraviolet radiation, air pollutants and some biological materials. The effects of these immunotoxic substances have been shown to alter both the innate and adaptive parts of the immune system. Consequences of xenobiotics affect the organ initially in contact. Some commonly seen problems that arise as a result of contact with immunotoxic substances are: immunosuppression, hypersensitivity, and autoimmunity. The toxin-induced immune dysfunction may also increase susceptibility to cancer. The study of immunotoxicology began in the 1970s.

Immunotoxicology is the study of the impact of foreign substances, known as xenobiotics, on the immune system. These substances can include industrial chemicals, heavy metals, agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, drugs, ultraviolet radiation, air pollutants, and some biological materials. The effects of these can alter both innate and adaptive immune responses. Common issues arising from contact with immunotoxic substances can be immunosuppression, hypersensitivity, autoimmunity, and increased susceptibility to cancer. This field of study started in the 1970s.
What is immunopharmacology?

Immunopharmacology, as its name suggests, is the branch of pharmacology that applies to the immune system. In general immunopharmacology describes the manipulation of the immune system and immune responses by pharmacological modulators, for the benefit of the host. This is an immense, and continually expanding field.

Immunopharmacology is a branch of pharmacology that deals with the immune system and its responses. It involves the manipulation of the immune system and immune responses through pharmacological modulators for the benefit of the host. It's a continually expanding and immense field.
What is immunoprophylaxis?

1. Preexposure immunoprophylaxis a. Inactivated HAV vaccine Highly effective (efficacy rate, 95% to 100%); proven to be as effective as a live attenuated virus vaccine. One study has shown that one or two doses of inactivated vaccine achieve 93% to 100% seroprotection compared with 65% with one dose of the live attenuated HAV vaccine.

Immunoprophylaxis refers to measures taken to prevent disease or infection by stimulating the immune response. This is often achieved through vaccines, such as the inactivated HAV vaccine mentioned in the text. This vaccine is highly effective with an efficacy rate of 95% to 100%. One study has shown that one or two doses of the inactivated vaccine achieve 93% to 100% seroprotection.
What is immunohematology?

Immunohematology is a branch of hematology and transfusion medicine which studies antigen-antibody reactions and analogous phenomena as they relate to the pathogenesis and clinical manifestations of blood disorders. A person employed in this field is referred to as an immunohematologist or colloquially as a blood banker. Their day-to-day duties include blood typing, cross-matching and antibody identification. Immunohematology and Transfusion Medicine is a medical post graduate specialty in many countries. The specialist Immunohematology and Transfusion Physician provides expert opinion for difficult transfusions, massive transfusions, incompatibility work up, therapeutic plasmapheresis, cellular therapy, irradiated blood therapy, leukoreduced and washed blood products, stem cell procedures, platelet rich plasma therapies, HLA and cord blood banking. Other research avenues are in the field of stem cell researches, regenerative medicine and cellular therapy.

Immunohematology is a branch of hematology and transfusion medicine which focuses on antigen-antibody reactions and similar phenomena as they relate to the development and clinical manifestations of blood disorders. An immunohematologist, also known as a blood banker, is responsible for blood typing, cross-matching, and antibody identification. Experts in this field can also provide opinions for difficult transfusions, massive transfusions, therapeutic plasmapheresis, cellular therapy, irradiated blood therapy, leukoreduced and washed blood products, stem cell procedures, and more. They also have roles in stem cell research, regenerative medicine and cellular therapy.
What is immunodermatology?

Immunodermatology studies skin as an organ of immunity in health and disease. Several areas have special attention, such as photo-immunology, inflammatory diseases such as Hidradenitis suppurativa, allergic contact dermatitis and atopic eczema, presumably autoimmune skin diseases such as vitiligo and psoriasis, and finally the immunology of microbial skin diseases such as retrovirus infections and leprosy. New therapies in development for the immunomodulation of common immunological skin diseases include biologicals aimed at neutralizing TNF-alfa and chemokine receptor inhibitors.

Immunodermatology is the study of the skin, regarding it as an organ of immunity in both health and disease. It focuses on several areas. Photo-immunology studies the effects of light on skin immunity. It deals with inflammatory diseases like Hidradenitis suppurativa, allergic contact dermatitis and atopic eczema. It also covers potentially autoimmune skin conditions such as vitiligo and psoriasis. Furthermore, it involves the study of immunity in microbial skin conditions like retrovirus infections and leprosy. New treatments being developed include biologicals that neutralize TNF-alfa and chemokine receptor inhibitors to control common immune skin conditions.
What is immunocontraception?

Immunocontraception is the use of an animal's immune system to prevent it from fertilizing offspring. Contraceptives of this type are not currently approved for human use. Typically immunocontraception involves the administration of a vaccine that induces an adaptive immune response which causes an animal to become temporarily infertile. Contraceptive vaccines have been used in numerous settings for the control of wildlife populations. However, experts in the field believe that major innovations are required before immunocontraception can become a practical form of contraception for human beings. Thus far immunocontraception has focused on mammals exclusively. There are several targets in mammalian sexual reproduction for immune inhibition. They can be organized into three categories.

Immunocontraception is a method of contraception that uses the immune system to prevent fertility, primarily used in animals. It works by administering a vaccine that leads to an adaptive immune response, causing temporary infertility. While it has been used for wildlife population control, immunocontraception is not yet approved for human use, as more innovations are required for it to be a practical form of contraception for humans. Currently, immunocontraception targets are based on mammalian sexual reproduction and can be organized into three categories.
What is autoimmunity?

In immunology, autoimmunity is the system of immune responses of an organism against its own healthy cells, tissues and other normal body constituents. Any disease resulting from this type of immune response is termed an \"autoimmune disease\". Prominent examples include celiac disease, diabetes mellitus type 1, Henoch\u2013Sch\u00f6nlein purpura, systemic lupus erythematosus, Sj\u00f6gren syndrome, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Graves' disease, idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, Addison's disease, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and multiple sclerosis. Autoimmune diseases are very often treated with steroids. Autoimmunity means presence of antibodies or T cells that react with self-protein and is present in all individuals, even in normal health state. It causes autoimmune diseases if self-reactivity can lead to tissue damage.

Autoimmunity refers to the immune system's responses against the organism's own healthy cells and tissues. It is a normal occurrence in all individuals, but when this self-reactivity causes tissue damage, it results in autoimmune diseases. Some examples of autoimmune diseases include celiac disease, type 1 diabetes, lupus, Sj\u00f6gren syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis. These diseases are often treated with steroids.
