What is the Krebs Cycle?

The citric acid cycle\u2014also known as the Krebs cycle, Szent-Gy\u00f6rgyi-Krebs cycle or the TCA cycle\u2014is a series of biochemical reactions to release the energy stored in nutrients through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. The chemical energy released is available under the form of ATP. The Krebs cycle is used by organisms that respire to generate energy, either by anaerobic respiration or aerobic respiration. In addition, the cycle provides precursors of certain amino acids, as well as the reducing agent NADH, that are used in numerous other reactions. Its central importance to many biochemical pathways suggests that it was one of the earliest components of metabolism. Even though it is branded as a 'cycle', it is not necessary for metabolites to follow only one specific route; at least three alternative segments of the citric acid cycle have been recognized.

The Krebs Cycle, also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle, is a series of biochemical reactions used by respiring organisms to release stored energy from nutrients. Acetyl-CoA, derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins, undergoes oxidation. The chemical energy is released in the form of ATP. The cycle also provides precursors of certain amino acids and the reducing agent NADH, used in many other reactions. Although called a 'cycle', metabolites do not necessarily follow one specific route, and at least three alternative segments of the citric acid cycle have been recognized.
What is the function of the mitochondria?
Mitochondria are organelles that produce energy (ATP) for eukaryotic cells. They have two membranes, a unique genome, and a role in calcium storage, heat production, and cell death.

The mitochondria have several important functions in the cell. They produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP, store calcium, help in heat production, and play a role in cell death. They also have their own unique genome and two membranes.
What is the function of ribosomes?

Ribosomes are particles that synthesize proteins from genetic code carried by mRNA. They are composed of rRNA and proteins, and occur in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Learn more about their structure, function, and role in translation.

Ribosomes are particles that synthesize proteins from the genetic code carried by mRNA. They are composed of rRNA and proteins, and are found in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Their primary role is in translation, the process of constructing proteins.
What is the function of Golgi Bodies?

Golgi apparatus, membrane-bound organelle of eukaryotic cells (cells with clearly defined nuclei) that is made up of a series of flattened, stacked pouches called cisternae. The Golgi apparatus is responsible for transporting, modifying, and packaging proteins and lipids into vesicles for delivery to targeted destinations.

Golgi Bodies, also known as the Golgi apparatus, are a part of eukaryotic cells. They are made up of flattened, stacked pouches called cisternae. Their key functions are transporting, modifying, and packaging proteins and lipids into vesicles to be delivered to their required destinations within the cell.
What are the differences between plant cells and animal cells?

The differences between plant and animal cells cannot the naked eye. However, the impacts of these differences on the morphology (form and features) of plants and animals is noticeable. Without chloroplasts, a cell wall and a central vacuole, animals cells are able to do certain things that plant cells cannot, and vice versa. ...

The main differences between plant cells and animal cells are that plant cells have chloroplasts, a cell wall, and a central vacuole, all of which animal cells do not have. The presence of these elements in plant cells allows them to perform functions that animal cells cannot, and vice versa.
What is the cell cycle?

Cell Cycle is a biweekly peer-reviewed scientific journal covering all aspects of cell biology. It was established in 2002 with Mikhail V. Blagosklonny as founding editor-in-chief. Originally published bimonthly, it is now published biweekly.

The cell cycle is not a biological process as you may think. According to the information I found, 'Cell Cycle' is a biweekly peer-reviewed scientific journal that covers all aspects of cell biology. It was established in 2002 with Mikhail V. Blagosklonny as the founding editor-in-chief.
What is cellular respiration?

Cellular respiration is the process by which biological fuels are oxidized in the presence of an inorganic electron acceptor, such as oxygen, to drive the bulk production of adenosine triphosphate, which contains energy. Cellular respiration may be described as a set of metabolic reactions and processes that take place in the cells of organisms to convert chemical energy from nutrients into ATP, and then release waste products. Cellular respiration is a vital process that occurs in the cells of all living organisms. Respiration can be either aerobic, requiring oxygen, or anaerobic; some organisms can switch between aerobic and anaerobic respiration. The reactions involved in respiration are catabolic reactions, which break large molecules into smaller ones, producing large amounts of energy. Respiration is one of the key ways a cell releases chemical energy to fuel cellular activity. The overall reaction occurs in a series of biochemical steps, some of which are redox reactions.

Cellular respiration is a set of metabolic reactions that occur in the cells of organisms to convert chemical energy from nutrients into ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate), releasing waste products in the process. This vital process allows cells to release chemical energy that fuels cellular activity. Cellular respiration can be aerobic (requires oxygen) or anaerobic, and involves catabolic reactions that break large molecules into smaller ones, producing a large amount of energy. It's a process taking place in a series of biochemical steps, including redox reactions.
What are the laws of thermodynamics?

The laws of thermodynamics are a set of scientific laws which define a group of physical quantities, such as temperature, energy, and entropy, that characterize thermodynamic systems in thermodynamic equilibrium. The laws also use various parameters for thermodynamic processes, such as thermodynamic work and heat, and establish relationships ...

The laws of thermodynamics are scientific rules that define certain physical quantities such as temperature, energy, and entropy, with which thermodynamic systems in thermodynamic equilibrium can be characterized. These laws also use parameters for various thermodynamic processes like thermodynamic work and heat and set up relationships between them.
What is the theory of evolution?

Evolution is the change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations. Evolution occurs when evolutionary processes such as natural selection and genetic drift act on genetic variation, resulting in certain characteristics becoming more or less common within a population over successive generations. The process of evolution has given rise to biodiversity at every level of biological organisation. The theory of evolution by natural selection was conceived independently by Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace in the mid-19th century as an explanation for why organisms are adapted to their physical and biological environments. The theory was first set out in detail in Darwin's book On the Origin of Species.

The theory of evolution postulates that all life on Earth shares common ancestry and has changed over successive generations. Evolutionary processes such as natural selection and genetic drift act on genetic variation within a species, influencing the frequencies of different traits over time. This has led to the immense biodiversity we see today. This theory was independently conceived by Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace in the mid-19th century. It provides an explanation for why organisms are uniquely adapted to their physical and biological environments. A detailed explanation of this theory is found in Darwin's book On the Origin of Species.
Who proposed the theory of natural selection?

Natural Selection. First published Wed Sep 25, 2019. Charles Darwin and Alfred Wallace are the two co-discoverers of natural selection (Darwin & Wallace 1858), though, between the two, Darwin is the principal theorist of the notion whose most famous work on the topic is On the Origin of Species (Darwin 1859). For Darwin, natural selection is a ...
The theory of natural selection was proposed by Charles Darwin and Alfred Wallace.
What is genetic drift?

Genetic drift, also known as random genetic drift, allelic drift or the Wright effect, is the change in the frequency of an existing gene variant in a population due to random chance. Genetic drift may cause gene variants to disappear completely and thereby reduce genetic variation. It can also cause initially rare alleles to become much more frequent and even fixed. When few copies of an allele exist, the effect of genetic drift is more notable, and when many copies exist, the effect is less notable. In the middle of the 20th century, vigorous debates occurred over the relative importance of natural selection versus neutral processes, including genetic drift. Ronald Fisher, who explained natural selection using Mendelian genetics, held the view that genetic drift plays at most a minor role in evolution, and this remained the dominant view for several decades.

Genetic drift, also known as allelic drift or the Wright effect, is the change in the frequency of an existing gene variant in a population due to random chance. This can cause gene variants to disappear entirely and result in reduced genetic variation, or make initially rare alleles become much more frequent or even fixed. The effect of genetic drift is more noticeable when few copies of an allele exist, and less so when many copies exist. It has been a topic of debate regarding its relative importance compared to natural selection in the process of evolution.
What are the different types of speciation?

There are five types of speciation: allopatric, peripatric, parapatric, and sympatric and artificial. ... The two types of maggots are not different species yet, but many scientists believe they are undergoing the process of sympatric speciation. Artificial speciation (5) is the creation of new species by people. This is achieved through lab ...

The different types of speciation are allopatric, peripatric, parapatric, sympatric, and artificial. Allopatric speciation occurs when populations of the same species become geographically isolated whereas peripatric speciation is a kind of allopatric speciation that happens when a small population gets isolated at the edge of a larger population. Parapatric speciation occurs when populations are separated not by a geographical barrier, but an extreme change in habitat. Sympatric speciation occurs when new species evolve from a single ancestral species while inhabiting the same geographic region. Lastly, artificial speciation is the creation of new species by people usually accomplished through lab experiments or controlled breeding.
What is the carbon cycle?

The carbon cycle is that part of the biogeochemical cycle by which carbon is exchanged among the biosphere, pedosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere of Earth. Other major biogeochemical cycles include the nitrogen cycle and the water cycle. Carbon is the main component of biological compounds as well as a major component of many minerals such as limestone. The carbon cycle comprises a sequence of events that are key to making Earth capable of sustaining life. It describes the movement of carbon as it is recycled and reused throughout the biosphere, as well as long-term processes of carbon sequestration to and release from carbon sinks. To describe the dynamics of the carbon cycle, a distinction can be made between the fast and slow carbon cycle. The fast carbon cycle is also referred to as the biological carbon cycle. Fast carbon cycles can complete within years, moving substances from atmosphere to biosphere, then back to the atmosphere.

The carbon cycle is the process by which carbon is exchanged among Earth's biosphere, pedosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere. It is central for supporting life on Earth due to its role in the structure of biological compounds and minerals like limestone. The cycle involves the recycling and reuse of carbon throughout the biosphere and processes of carbon sequestration to and release from carbon sinks. The carbon cycle consists of two main cycles: the fast/biological cycle, which moves substances from the atmosphere to the biosphere and back within years, and the slow cycle, lasting over longer timescales.
What is the nitrogen cycle?

The nitrogen cycle is the biogeochemical cycle by which nitrogen is converted into multiple chemical forms as it circulates among atmospheric, terrestrial, and marine ecosystems. The conversion of nitrogen can be carried out through both biological and physical processes. Important processes in the nitrogen cycle include fixation, ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification. The majority of Earth's atmosphere is atmospheric nitrogen, making it the largest source of nitrogen. However, atmospheric nitrogen has limited availability for biological use, leading to a scarcity of usable nitrogen in many types of ecosystems. The nitrogen cycle is of particular interest to ecologists because nitrogen availability can affect the rate of key ecosystem processes, including primary production and decomposition. Human activities such as fossil fuel combustion, use of artificial nitrogen fertilizers, and release of nitrogen in wastewater have dramatically altered the global nitrogen cycle.

The nitrogen cycle is a process where nitrogen is converted into various chemical forms as it circulates among the atmosphere, terrestrial, and marine ecosystems. This conversion can occur via both biological and physical processes. Important stages in the nitrogen cycle include fixation, ammonification, nitrification, and denitrification. The majority of Earth's atmosphere is atmospheric nitrogen, but its limited availability for biological use results in a scarcity of usable nitrogen in many types of ecosystems. The nitrogen cycle is crucial for ecologists as nitrogen availability can affect key ecosystem processes, such as primary production and decomposition. This cycle has been significantly altered by human activities such as fossil fuel combustion, the use of artificial nitrogen fertilizers, and release of nitrogen in wastewater.
What are the different levels of ecological organization?

In the upper right hand corner of the image is a formula that states Community, biotic component + physical environment, abiotic component + interactions = Ecosystem. The diagram above will hopefully help you visualize how the different ecological levels are related to each other. Individuals make up a population; populations make up a species ...

The different levels of ecological organization, from smallest to largest, include: individuals, populations, species, communities, and ecosystems. An individual is a single organism, a population is a group of individuals of the same species living in a specific area, a species is a group of populations, a community comprises multiple living organisms in an area, and an ecosystem comprises both the biotic (living) community and its abiotic (non-living) environment, including their interactions.
What are the different types of ecosystems?

Coral reef ecosystems cover about one percent of the ocean floor but about 25% of fish species depend on coral reef ecosystems for survival. This is because coral reefs often serve as protection, breeding grounds, and food sources for many different fish and other marine species. 5. Oceanic Ecosystem.

There are various types of ecosystems, but one key example is the coral reef ecosystem. It may only cover approximately 1% of the ocean floor, but it is vital as about 25% of fish species depend on it for survival. It serves as a protective shell, a breeding ground, and a food source for a wide variety of marine species. Another type of ecosystem is the Oceanic Ecosystem.
What is ecological succession?

Ecological succession is the process of change in the species that make up an ecological community over time. The process of succession occurs either after the initial colonization of a newly created habitat, or after a disturbance substantially alters a pre-existing habitat. Succession that begins in new habitats, uninfluenced by pre-existing communities, is called primary succession, whereas succession that follows disruption of a pre-existing community is called secondary succession. Primary succession may happen after a lava flow or the emergence of a new island from the ocean. Surtsey, a volcanic island off the southern coast of Iceland, is an important example of a place where primary succession has been observed. On the other hand, secondary succession happens after disturbance of a community, such as from a fire, severe windthrow, or logging. Succession was among the first theories advanced in ecology.

Ecological succession is the change in species that form an ecological community over a period of time. This process can occur after the initial colonization of a newly created habitat, or after a significant disturbance to an existing habitat. If the succession begins in new habitats with no influence from pre-existing communities, it is termed as primary succession. Examples of primary succession include lava flows or the emergence of new islands. Conversely, secondary succession occurs after a community has been disrupted, for instance, due to a fire, severe windthrow or logging. This concept is one of the earliest theories in ecology.
What is photosynthesis?

Photosynthesis is a system of biological processes by which photosynthetic organisms, such as most plants, algae, and cyanobacteria, convert light energy, typically from sunlight, into the chemical energy necessary to fuel their activities. Photosynthetic organisms use intracellular organic compounds to store the chemical energy they produce in photosynthesis. Photosynthesis is usually used to refer to oxygenic photosynthesis, a form of photosynthesis where the photosynthetic processes produce oxygen as a byproduct and synthesize carbohydrate molecules like sugars, starches, glycogen, and cellulose to store the chemical energy. To use the chemical energy stored in these organic compounds, the organisms' cells metabolize the organic compounds through another process called cellular respiration.

Photosynthesis is a biological process performed by photosynthetic organisms like plants, algae, and certain bacteria. They convert light energy, typically from the sun, into chemical energy to fuel their activities. During photosynthesis, these organisms produce oxygen as a byproduct and synthesize carbohydrate molecules such as sugars and starches to store the generated chemical energy. This stored energy is later released by the process of cellular respiration.
What is fermentation?

Fermentation is a metabolic process that produces chemical changes in organic substances through the action of enzymes. In biochemistry, it is broadly defined as the extraction of energy from carbohydrates in the absence of oxygen. In food production, it may more broadly refer to any process in which the activity of microorganisms brings about a desirable change to a foodstuff or beverage. The science of fermentation is known as zymology. In microorganisms, fermentation is the primary means of producing adenosine triphosphate by the degradation of organic nutrients anaerobically. Humans have used fermentation to produce foodstuffs and beverages since the Neolithic age. For example, fermentation is used for preservation in a process that produces lactic acid found in such sour foods as pickled cucumbers, kombucha, kimchi, and yogurt, as well as for producing alcoholic beverages such as wine and beer.

Fermentation is a metabolic process that creates chemical changes in organic substances through enzymes. It's well-defined as the extraction of energy from carbohydrates in the absence of oxygen. Fermentation is particularly beneficial in terms of food production as it allows microorganisms to make desirable changes in foodstuffs or beverages. This includes preservation processes that yield lactic acid in food items like pickled cucumbers, kombucha, kimchi, and yogurt, and also the production of alcoholic beverages like wine and beer. Additionally, microorganisms use fermentation as a main way to produce adenosine triphosphate (ATP) by the degradation of organic nutrients without oxygen. Humans have used this method of fermentation since the Neolithic age. The science studying fermentation is known as zymology.
What are biotic and abiotic factors?

A biotic factor is a living thing that has an impact on another population of living things or on the environment. Abiotic factors do the same thing, but they are non-living. Together, biotic and abiotic factors make up an ecosystem. To survive, biotic factors need abiotic factors. In turn, biotic factors can limit the kinds and amounts of ...

Biotic factors are living things that have an impact on another population of living things or the environment. These can include animals, plants, fungi, bacteria, etc. On the other hand, abiotic factors are non-living things that also impact the environment and the living organisms within it. These can include sunlight, temperature, wind patterns, rocks, soil, etc. Together, these biotic and abiotic factors make up an ecosystem, with each depending on the other to survive and thrive.
What is the food chain?

A food chain is a linear network of links in a food web starting from producer organisms and ending at an apex predator species, detritivores, or decomposer species. A food chain also shows how organisms are related to each other by the food they eat. Each level of a food chain represents a different trophic level. A food chain differs from a food web because the complex network of different animals' feeding relations are aggregated and the chain only follows a direct, linear pathway of one animal at a time. Natural interconnections between food chains make it a food web. Food Chains were first discussed by al-Jahiz, a 10th century Arab philosopher. The modern concepts of food chains and food webs were introduced by Charles Elton. A common metric used to quantify food web trophic structure is food chain length. In its simplest form, the length of a chain is the number of links between a trophic consumer and the base of the web.

A food chain is a linear network of links in a food web that begins with producer organisms and ends at an apex predator species, detritivores, or decomposer species. Each level of a food chain represents a different trophic level. The concept of a food chain differs from a food web in that a food chain follows a direct, linear pathway of one animal at a time. The ideas of food chains and food webs were introduced by Charles Elton. A common metric used to measure food web trophic structure is food chain length. In simplest terms, the length of a chain is the number of links between a trophic consumer and the base of the web.
What is the food web?

A food web is the natural interconnection of food chains and a graphical representation of what-eats-what in an ecological community. Ecologists can broadly define all life forms as either autotrophs or heterotrophs, based on their trophic levels, the position that they occupy in the food web. To maintain their bodies, grow, develop, and to reproduce, autotrophs produce organic matter from inorganic substances, including both minerals and gases such as carbon dioxide. These chemical reactions require energy, which mainly comes from the Sun and largely by photosynthesis, although a very small amount comes from bioelectrogenesis in wetlands, and mineral electron donors in hydrothermal vents and hot springs.

A food web is a graphical representation that shows the interconnection of food chains in an ecological community. It illustrates what organism eats what. Life forms can be divided into two categories based on their positions in the food web: autotrophs, who create organic matter from inorganic substances like minerals and gases, and heterotrophs. Most of the energy needed for these reactions comes from the Sun and is facilitated by photosynthesis, but a small amount can also come from bioelectrogenesis in wetlands, and from hydrothermal vents and hot springs which provide mineral electron donors.
What are trophic levels?

Trophic Level Definition. A trophic level is the group of organisms within an ecosystem which occupy the same level in a food chain.There are five main trophic levels within a food chain, each of which differs in its nutritional relationship with the primary energy source.The primary energy source in any ecosystem is the Sun (although there are exceptions in deep sea ecosystems).

Trophic levels refer to the group of organisms within an ecosystem that occupy the same level in a food chain. There are typically five main trophic levels, all differing in their nutritional relationship with the primary energy source. For the majority of ecosystems, the primary energy source is the Sun, but in certain systems like those in the deep sea, there are exceptions.
What is the difference between a population and a community?

Learn the main difference between a population and a community in biology, and how they differ in size, diversity, gene flow, structure, behavior, and predators. Also, discover how populations and communities are part of the larger context of ecosystems and how they interact with one another and the environment.

A population in biology refers to all the individuals of a specific species living in a specific area, typically characterized by similar structure, behavior, and gene flow. A community, on the other hand, is broader and encompasses all the different species living together in a specific area, having greater diversity. Both populations and communities interact with one another and form part of larger systems known as ecosystems, where they also interact with the environment.
What are the different types of symbiotic relationships?

Symbiosis Definition. A symbiosis is an evolved interaction or close living relationship between organisms from different species, usually with benefits to one or both of the individuals involved. Symbioses may be 'obligate', in which case the relationship between the two species is so interdependent, that each of the organisms is unable to ...

Symbiosis is an evolved interaction or close living relationship between organisms from different species. It is usually beneficial to one or both of the individuals involved. Some symbioses are 'obligate', meaning the relationship between the two species is so interdependent, that each of the organisms is unable to survive without the other.
What is global warming?

Global warming is the phenomenon of increasing average air temperatures near Earth's surface over the past century, mainly due to human activities that increase greenhouse gases. Learn about the causes, effects, solutions, and facts of global warming from Britannica, a trusted source of scientific information.

Global warming is the increase in average air temperatures near Earth's surface over the past century. This is primarily due to human activities that raise levels of greenhouse gases. It can cause numerous environmental changes and issues, but solutions are being sought. For more detailed information, you might want to consult authoritative sources like Britannica.
What is climate change?

In common usage, climate change describes global warming\u2014the ongoing increase in global average temperature\u2014and its effects on Earth's climate system. Climate change in a broader sense also includes previous long-term changes to Earth's climate. The current rise in global average temperature is more rapid than previous changes, and is primarily caused by humans burning fossil fuels. Fossil fuel use, deforestation, and some agricultural and industrial practices add to greenhouse gases, notably carbon dioxide and methane. Greenhouse gases absorb some of the heat that the Earth radiates after it warms from sunlight. Larger amounts of these gases trap more heat in Earth's lower atmosphere, causing global warming. Climate change has an increasingly large impact on the environment. Deserts are expanding, while heat waves and wildfires are becoming more common. Amplified warming in the Arctic has contributed to thawing permafrost, retreat of glaciers and sea ice decline.

Climate change refers to the ongoing increase in global average temperature and its effects on Earth's climate system. It's caused primarily by human activities such as burning of fossil fuels, deforestation, and some agricultural and industrial practices which increase greenhouse gases, particularly carbon dioxide and methane. These gases trap heat in Earth's lower atmosphere causing global warming. Climate change is having significant impacts on the environment, with deserts expanding, heat waves and wildfires becoming more common and amplified warming in the Arctic leading to thawing permafrost, retreat of glaciers and sea ice decline.
What is a greenhouse gas?

Greenhouse gases trap some of the heat that results when sunlight heats the Earth's surface. Three important greenhouse gases are shown symbolically in this image: carbon dioxide, water vapor, and methane. The extent to which particular greenhouse gases are causing climate change, along with other factors.. Greenhouse gases are the gases in the atmosphere that raise the surface temperature of ...

Greenhouse gases are gases in the Earth's atmosphere that trap heat from the sunlight, which leads to the heating of the Earth's surface. Three significant examples of these types of gases are carbon dioxide, water vapor, and methane. These gases are considered contributing factors to climate change due to their heat-trapping nature.
What is ozone layer depletion?

Ozone depletion consists of two related events observed since the late 1970s: a steady lowering of about four percent in the total amount of ozone in Earth's atmosphere, and a much larger springtime decrease in stratospheric ozone around Earth's polar regions. The latter phenomenon is referred to as the ozone hole. There are also springtime polar tropospheric ozone depletion events in addition to these stratospheric events. The main causes of ozone depletion and the ozone hole are manufactured chemicals, especially manufactured halocarbon refrigerants, solvents, propellants, and foam-blowing agents, referred to as ozone-depleting substances. These compounds are transported into the stratosphere by turbulent mixing after being emitted from the surface, mixing much faster than the molecules can settle. Once in the stratosphere, they release atoms from the halogen group through photodissociation, which catalyze the breakdown of ozone into oxygen.

Ozone layer depletion refers to a steady decrease of about four percent in the total amount of ozone in Earth's atmosphere, observed since the late 1970s. Additionally, more severe decreases occur in the springtime around Earth's polar regions, known as an ozone hole. Ozone depletion is primarily caused by man-made chemicals such as halocarbon refrigerants, solvents, propellants, and foam-blowing agents, which are collectively referred to as ozone-depleting substances. These substances are released into the stratosphere where, through a process known as photodissociation, they release halogen atoms that catalyze the breakdown of ozone into oxygen.
What is pollution?

Pollution is the introduction of contaminants into the natural environment that cause adverse change. Pollution can take the form of any substance or energy. Pollutants, the components of pollution, can be either foreign substances/energies or naturally occurring contaminants. Although environmental pollution can be caused by natural events, the word pollution generally implies that the contaminants have an anthropogenic source \u2013 that is, a source created by human activities, such as manufacturing, extractive industries, poor waste management, transportation or agriculture. Pollution is often classed as point source or nonpoint source pollution. Many sources of pollution were unregulated parts of industrialization during the 19th and 20th centuries until the emergence of environmental regulation and pollution policy in the later half of the 20th century.

Pollution refers to the introduction of harmful materials, referred to as pollutants, into the environment. These pollutants can be either foreign substances or naturally occurring contaminants. Although sometimes pollution can be the result of natural events, the term generally implies that the contaminants have a human source, such as industrial activities, waste management, transportation, or agriculture. Pollution can be categorized as point source or nonpoint source pollution. The regulation and policy regarding environmental pollution started to emerge in the latter half of the 20th century.
What is the ecological footprint?

The ecological footprint measures human demand on natural capital, i.e. the quantity of nature it takes to support people and their economies. It tracks human demand on nature through an ecological accounting system. The accounts contrast the biologically productive area people use to satisfy their consumption to the biologically productive area available within a region, nation, or the world. Biocapacity is the productive area that can regenerate what people demand from nature. Therefore, the metric is a measure of human impact on the environment. As Ecological Footprint accounts measure to what extent human activities operate within the means of our planet, they are a central metric for sustainability. The metric is promoted by the Global Footprint Network which has developed standards to make results comparable. FoDaFo, supported by Global Footprint Network and York University are now providing the national assessments of Footprints and biocapacity.

The ecological footprint measures human demand on nature. It calculates the quantity of nature it takes to support people and their economies, contrasting the biologically productive area people use for their consumption to the biologically productive area available within a region, nation, or the world. It represents the human impact on the environment and is a crucial metric for sustainability. This measurement is promoted and made comparable by standards developed by the Global Footprint Network.
What is an endangered species?

An endangered species is a type of organism that is threatened by extinction. Species become endangered for two main reasons: loss of habitat and loss of genetic variation. Loss of Habitat A loss of habitat can happen naturally. Dinosaurs, for instance, lost their habitat about 65 million years ago.

An endangered species is a type of organism that is threatened by extinction. This can occur for two main reasons: loss of habitat and loss of genetic variation. A habitat loss can even occur naturally, such as the case with dinosaurs, which lost their habitat about 65 million years ago.
What is deforestation?

Deforestation or forest clearance is the removal and destruction of a forest or stand of trees from land that is then converted to non-forest use. Deforestation can involve conversion of forest land to farms, ranches, or urban use. The most concentrated deforestation occurs in tropical rainforests. About 31% of Earth's land surface is covered by forests at present. This is one-third less than the forest cover before the expansion of agriculture, with half of that loss occurring in the last century. Between 15 million to 18 million hectares of forest, an area the size of Bangladesh, are destroyed every year. On average 2,400 trees are cut down each minute. The overwhelming direct cause of deforestation is agriculture. More than 80% of deforestation was attributed to agriculture in 2018. Forests are being converted to plantations for coffee, tea, palm oil, rice, rubber, and various other popular products. Livestock ranching is another agricultural activity that drives deforestation.

Deforestation is the process of removing and destructing forests for non-forest uses such as farms, ranches, or urban uses. This is highly concentrated in tropical rainforests. Currently, 31% of Earth's land is covered by forests, which is one-third less than the forest cover before the expansion of agriculture. Each year, about 15 to 18 million hectares of forest are destroyed - on average, 2,400 trees are cut down each minute. The main cause of deforestation is agriculture, accounting for more than 80% of deforestation in 2018. This is because forests are converted into plantations for producing coffee, tea, palm oil, rice, rubber, and other products. Livestock ranching also contributes to deforestation.
What is a bioindicator?

Bioindicator. Caddisfly (order Trichoptera ), a macroinvertebrate used as an indicator of water quality. [1] A bioindicator is any species (an indicator species) or group of species whose function, population, or status can reveal the qualitative status of the environment. The most common indicator species are animals. [2]

A bioindicator is any species or group of species whose function, population, or status can reveal the qualitative status of the environment. The most commonly used indicator species are animals. For example, the caddisfly is a macroinvertebrate used as an indicator of water quality.
What are the different types of ecosystems?

Coral reef ecosystems cover about one percent of the ocean floor but about 25% of fish species depend on coral reef ecosystems for survival. This is because coral reefs often serve as protection, breeding grounds, and food sources for many different fish and other marine species. 5. Oceanic Ecosystem.

One type of ecosystem is the coral reef ecosystem, which covers about one percent of the ocean floor. Despite this small percentage, around 25% of fish species rely on these ecosystems for survival as they provide protection, breeding grounds, and sources of food.
What is biodiversity?

Biodiversity or biological diversity is the variety and variability of life on Earth. Biodiversity is a measure of variation at the genetic, species, and ecosystem levels. Biodiversity is not distributed evenly on Earth; it is usually greater in the tropics as a result of the warm climate and high primary productivity in the region near the equator. Tropical forest ecosystems cover less than 10% of Earth's terrestrial surface and contain about 50% of the world's species. There are latitudinal gradients in species diversity for both marine and terrestrial taxa. Terrestrial species threatened with mass extinction can be observed in exceptionally dense regional biodiversity hotspots, with high levels of species endemism under threat. There are 36 such hotspot regions which require the world's attention in order to secure global biodiversity. More than 99.9% of all species that ever lived on Earth, amounting to over five billion species, are estimated to be extinct.

Biodiversity, also known as biological diversity, refers to the variety and variability of life on Earth. This diversity is measured at three levels: genetic, species, and ecosystem. The distribution of biodiversity is not even on Earth; it is generally higher in the tropics due to the warm climate and high productivity near the equator. Despite covering less than 10% of Earth's terrestrial surface, tropical forests are home to about 50% of the world's species. There's also a noted change in species diversity from the poles towards the equator for both marine and terrestrial species. Importantly, areas known as biodiversity hotspots, which boast exceptionally high species endemism under threat, currently face the possible extinction of terrestrial species. Overall, more than 99.9% of all species that have ever lived on Earth, estimated to be over five billion, are thought to be extinct.
What is conservation biology?

Conservation biology is the study of the conservation of nature and of Earth's biodiversity with the aim of protecting species, their habitats, and ecosystems from excessive rates of extinction and the erosion of biotic interactions. It is an interdisciplinary subject drawing on natural and social sciences, and the practice of natural resource management. The conservation ethic is based on the findings of conservation biology.

Conservation biology is the interdisciplinary study focused on the conservation of nature and Earth's biodiversity. It aims to protect species, their habitats, and ecosystems from high rates of extinction and deterioration of biological interactions. It draws knowledge from both natural and social sciences, along with the practice of natural resource management. The conservation ethic is founded on the findings of conservation biology.
What are ecosystem services?

Ecosystem services are the direct and indirect contributions of ecosystems to human well-being, such as food, water, climate regulation, cultural enrichment and habitat functioning. Learn about the four types of ecosystem services, their importance, threats and examples.

Ecosystem services refer to the direct and indirect contributions that ecosystems provide for human well-being. These can include food, water, climate regulation, cultural enrichment, and habitat functioning. There are four types of these services, each with their own importance and potential threats. Examples can range from a forest providing wood for building materials to a lake serving as a recreational spot for individuals.
What is a keystone species?

A keystone species is an organism that helps hold the system together of any ecosystem, such as a predator, an ecosystem engineer, or a mutualist. Learn how keystone species affect the survival of other species and the environment, and see examples of different types of keystone species in marine and terrestrial ecosystems.

A keystone species is an organism that plays a significant role in holding the ecosystem together. They are vital since they affect the survival of other species and the environment. Keystone species can be predators, ecosystem engineers, or mutualists, and they exist in both marine and terrestrial ecosystems.
What are renewable energy sources?
Renewable energy sources are plentiful and all around us. Fossil fuels - coal, oil and gas - on the other hand, are non-renewable resources that take hundreds of millions of years to form. Fossil ...

Renewable energy sources are plentiful and exist naturally in the environment. Unlike non-renewable resources like coal, oil, and gas, which take hundreds of millions of years to form, renewable resources regenerate naturally and are constantly available.
What is habitat destruction?

Habitat destruction occurs when a natural habitat is no longer able to support its native species. The organisms once living there have either moved to elsewhere or are dead, leading to a decrease in biodiversity and species numbers. Habitat destruction is in fact the leading cause of biodiversity loss and species extinction worldwide. Humans contribute to habitat destruction through the use of natural resources, agriculture, industrial production and urbanization. Other activities include mining, logging and trawling. Environmental factors can contribute to habitat destruction more indirectly. Geological processes, climate change, introduction of invasive species, ecosystem nutrient depletion, water and noise pollution are some examples. Loss of habitat can be preceded by an initial habitat fragmentation. Fragmentation and loss of habitat have become one of the most important topics of research in ecology as they are major threats to the survival of endangered species.

Habitat destruction is when a natural habitat is altered to the extent that it can no longer support the species that live there. This often results in a decrease in biodiversity and can lead to species extinction. Humans are a significant contributor to habitat destruction through actions like urbanization, mining, logging, and agriculture. Other factors, such as climate change, invasive species, and pollution, can also contribute to habitat destruction indirectly. It's a significant concern in ecology due to its harmful impact on endangered species.
What are invasive species?

An invasive species is an organism that is not indigenous, or native, to a particular area. Invasive species can cause great economic and environmental harm to the new area. Not all non-native species are invasive. For example, most of the food crops grown in the United States, including popular varieties of wheat, tomatoes, and rice, are not native to the region.

Invasive species are organisms that are not indigenous, or native, to a particular area. They can cause great economic and environmental harm to the new area they inhabit. However, it's worth noting that not all non-native species are considered invasive. Many of them, such as popular varieties of wheat, tomatoes, and rice, are mainly food crops grown in the United States and do not pose any detriment to their environment.
What is overpopulation in ecology?

Overpopulation refers to a population which exceeds its sustainable size within a particular environment or habitat. Overpopulation results from an increased birth rate, decreased death rate, the immigration to a new ecological niche with fewer predators, or the sudden decline in available resources.

Overpopulation in ecology refers to a situation where a population exceeds its sustainable size within a particular environment or habitat. This can happen due to an increase in birth rate, a decrease in death rate, immigration to a new ecological niche with fewer predators, or a sudden decline in available resources.
What is desertification?

Desertification is a type of land degradation in drylands in which biological productivity is lost due to natural processes or induced by human activities whereby fertile areas become arid. It is the spread of arid areas caused by a variety of factors, such as overexploitation of soil as a result of human activity and the effects of climate change. Geographic areas most affected include the Sahel region in Africa, the Gobi Desert and Mongolia in Asia as well as parts of South America. Drylands occupy approximately 40\u201341% of Earth's land area and are home to more than 2 billion people. Effects of desertification include sand and dust storms, food insecurity, vegetation patterning and increasing poverty. There are many possible countermeasures such as reforestation, soil restoration, desert reclamation and managed grazing. Throughout geological history, the development of deserts has occurred naturally.

Desertification is a form of land degradation that occurs in drylands. It is when fertile areas become increasingly arid, often as a result of a variety of factors such as human activities and climate change. This loss of biological productivity can lead to issues like sand and dust storms, food insecurity, changing vegetation patterns and increased poverty. Some areas most impacted by this process include the Sahel region in Africa, the Gobi Desert and Mongolia in Asia, and parts of South America. There are potential solutions to this issue, including reforestation, soil restoration, desert reclamation, and regulated grazing.
What is eutrophication?

Eutrophication is a general term describing a process in which nutrients accumulate in a body of water, resulting in an increased growth of microorganisms that may deplete the water of oxygen. Although eutrophication is a natural process and, manmade or cultural eutrophication is far more common and is a rapid process caused by a variety of polluting inputs including poorly treated sewage, industrial wastewater, and fertilizer runoff. Such nutrient pollution usually causes algal blooms and bacterial growth, resulting in the depletion of dissolved oxygen in water and causing substantial environmental degradation. Approaches for prevention and reversal of eutrophication include minimizing point source pollution from sewage and agriculture as well as other nonpoint pollution sources.

Eutrophication is when nutrients accumulate in a body of water, leading to increased growth of microorganisms that can deplete the water's oxygen. This process, which can be natural or manmade, commonly causes algal blooms and bacterial growth, resulting in substantial environmental degradation. Human contributions to eutrophication often come from poorly treated sewage, industrial wastewater, and fertilizer runoff. Approaches for preventing and reversing eutrophication include minimizing point source pollution from sewage and agriculture, as well as other nonpoint pollution sources.
What is a biome?

A biome ( / \u02c8ba\u026a.o\u028am /) is a distinct geographical region with specific climate, vegetation, and animal life. It consists of a biological community that has formed in response to its physical environment and regional climate. [1] [2] Biomes may span more than one continent. A biome encompasses multiple ecosystems within its boundaries.

A biome is a distinct geographical region characterized by its specific climate, vegetation, and animal life. It's basically a biological community that forms based on the physical environment and regional climate. A biome can span multiple continents and encompasses many ecosystems within its boundaries.
What is a biosphere?

The biosphere is made up of the parts of Earth where life exists. The biosphere extends from the deepest root systems of trees, to the dark environment of ocean trenches, to lush rainforests and high mountaintops. Scientists describe Earth in terms of spheres. The solid surface layer of Earth is the lithosphere.The atmosphere is the layer of air that stretches above the lithosphere.

The biosphere is the part of the Earth where life exists. It extends from the deepest root systems of trees, to the darkest parts of the ocean trenches, to the richness of rainforests and high mountaintops. It's essentially the living layer of the world, interacting with the solid surface layer (the lithosphere) and the layer of air above it (the atmosphere).
What is an ecological niche?

An ecological niche is the role an organism plays within its habitat. It depends on both biotic and abiotic factors, such as food availability and predators. Learn how ecologists use the concept of the niche to understand how species interact within ecosystems and how they coexist or compete with other species. See examples of different types of niches and how they affect the environment.

An ecological niche refers to the role an organism plays within its habitat. This role is influenced by both biotic and abiotic factors such as food availability and predators. Ecologists use this concept to understand species interactions within ecosystems and to decipher how they coexist or compete with other species.
What is a taxon?

In biology, a taxon ( back-formation from taxonomy; pl.: taxa) is a group of one or more populations of an organism or organisms seen by taxonomists to form a unit. Although neither is required, a taxon is usually known by a particular name and given a particular ranking, especially if and when it is accepted or becomes established.

A taxon in biology is a group of one or more populations of an organism or organisms, which are seen by taxonomists to form a unit. This unit is usually known by a particular name and given a specific ranking, especially if it is accepted or becomes established.
What is the hierarchy of biological classification?

The hierarchy of biological classification, also known as taxonomic hierarchy, is the process of arranging various organisms into successive levels of the biological classification either in a decreasing or an increasing order. It is a main function of Taxonomy which is a branch of Biology.

A phylogenetic tree is a diagram that represents evolutionary relationships among organisms. This is based on their common ancestors. It helps in understanding how one species is related to another in the tree of life.
What is an organism?

An organism is a single individual, or being, that cannot survive without its parts. Learn about the three domains of organisms, bacteria, archaea and eukarya, and their characteristics, functions and examples.

An organism is a single individual or being that cannot survive without its parts. There are three domains of organisms which include bacteria, archaea, and eukarya, each having their own characteristics, functions, and examples.
What is a species?

A species (pl. species) is often defined as the largest group of organisms in which any two individuals of the appropriate sexes or mating types can produce fertile offspring, typically by sexual reproduction. It is the basic unit of classification and a taxonomic rank of an organism, as well as a unit of biodiversity.

A species is the largest group of organisms where any two individuals of appropriate sexes or mating types can produce fertile offspring, typically through sexual reproduction. It is a unit of biodiversity and a basic unit of classification and taxonomic rank of an organism.

What is a class in biology?

What is an order in biology?

Order in biology is a major hierarchical taxonomic rank that is classified between family and class. It is used in the classification of organisms. Occasionally, an even higher rank, superorder, is added.

In biology, a family is one of the nine major hierarchical taxonomic ranks in Linnaean taxonomy. It is classified between order and genus. A family may also be divided into subfamilies, which are intermediate ranks between the ranks of family and genus. The official family names are Latin in origin.

What is a population Pyramid?

A population pyramid is a graph that shows the distribution of ages across a population divided by male and female members. It can be used to compare differences between male and female populations of an area, and to visualize how the population is changing over time. Learn about the three trends in population pyramids: expansive, constrictive, and stationary.

It's used to compare differences between male and female populations and visualize how the population changes over time. There are three trends in population pyramids: expansive, constrictive, and stationary.
What is population density?
Population density is a measurement of population per unit land area. It is mostly applied to humans, but sometimes to other living organisms too. It is a key geographical term.
Population density is a measure of the number of people per unit of land area. It is commonly used in geography and it can also be applied to other living organisms.
What is mass extinction?

An extinction event is a widespread and rapid decrease in the biodiversity on Earth. Such an event is identified by a sharp fall in the diversity and abundance of multicellular organisms. It occurs when the rate of extinction increases with respect to the background extinction rate and the rate of speciation. Estimates of the number of major mass extinctions in the last 540 million years range from as few as five to more than twenty. These differences stem from disagreement as to what constitutes a \"major\" extinction event, and the data chosen to measure past diversity.

Mass extinction, also known as an extinction event, is a rapid and widespread decrease in the biodiversity on Earth. It happens when the rate of extinction increases significantly compared to the usual, or 'background,' rate of extinction. This increase in extinction often surpasses the rate of new species development. Historically, estimates of the number of major mass extinctions throughout the last 540 million years range from five to over twenty, depending on the definition of a 'major' extinction event and the data used to measure past diversity.
What is extinction?

Extinction is the termination of a taxon by the death of its last member. A taxon may become functionally extinct before the death of its last member if it loses the capacity to reproduce and recover. Because a species' potential range may be very large, determining this moment is difficult, and is usually done retrospectively. This difficulty leads to phenomena such as Lazarus taxa, where a species presumed extinct abruptly \"reappears\" after a period of apparent absence. More than 99% of all species that ever lived on Earth, amounting to over five billion species, are estimated to have died out. It is estimated that there are currently around 8.7 million species of eukaryote globally, and possibly many times more if microorganisms, like bacteria, are included. Notable extinct animal species include non-avian dinosaurs, saber-toothed cats, dodos, mammoths, ground sloths, thylacines, trilobites, and golden toads.

Extinction refers to the termination of a taxon by the death of its last member. A species may become functionally extinct even before the death of its last member if it loses the ability to reproduce and recover. Determining when a species becomes extinct can be difficult and is usually decided retrospectively. There are instances like the Lazarus taxa, where a species that was presumed extinct suddenly 'reappears'. It is estimated that more than 99% of all species that ever lived on Earth, which is over five billion species, have died out. Currently, there are approximately 8.7 million species of eukaryote globally, with possibly many more if microorganisms like bacteria are included. Some notable extinct animal species include the non-avian dinosaurs, saber-toothed cats, dodos, mammoths, ground sloths, thylacines, trilobites, and golden toads.
What is a fossil record?

Fossil record, history of life as documented by fossils, the remains or imprints of organisms from earlier geological periods preserved in sedimentary rock. It is used to describe the evolution of groups of organisms and the environment in which they lived and to discover the age of the rock in which they are found.

A fossil record is the history of life as documented by fossils, which are the remains or imprints of organisms from earlier geological periods preserved in sedimentary rock. It is used to describe the evolution of groups of organisms and the environment in which they lived and also to discover the age of the rock in which they are found.
What is sedimentary rock?

Sedimentary rocks are types of rock that are formed by the accumulation or deposition of mineral or organic particles at Earth's surface, followed by cementation. Sedimentation is the collective name for processes that cause these particles to settle in place. The particles that form a sedimentary rock are called sediment, and may be composed of geological detritus or biological detritus. The geological detritus originated from weathering and erosion of existing rocks, or from the solidification of molten lava blobs erupted by volcanoes. The geological detritus is transported to the place of deposition by water, wind, ice or mass movement, which are called agents of denudation. Biological detritus was formed by bodies and parts of dead aquatic organisms, as well as their fecal mass, suspended in water and slowly piling up on the floor of water bodies. Sedimentation may also occur as dissolved minerals precipitate from water solution.

Sedimentary rocks are formed by the accumulation or deposition of mineral or organic particles at the Earth's surface, followed by cementation. These particles, known as sediment, may be composed of geological detritus (originating from weathering and erosion of existing rocks or the solidification of molten lava) or biological detritus (formed by bodies and parts of dead aquatic organisms). These sediments are transported to their place of deposition by water, wind, ice, or mass movement, termed as agents of denudation. In some cases, sedimentation may also occur when dissolved minerals precipitate from water solution.
What is radiometric dating?

Radiometric dating, radioactive dating or radioisotope dating is a technique which is used to date materials such as rocks or carbon, in which trace radioactive impurities were selectively incorporated when they were formed. The method compares the abundance of a naturally occurring radioactive isotope within the material to the abundance of its decay products, which form at a known constant rate of decay. The use of radiometric dating was first published in 1907 by Bertram Boltwood and is now the principal source of information about the absolute age of rocks and other geological features, including the age of fossilized life forms or the age of Earth itself, and can also be used to date a wide range of natural and man-made materials. Together with stratigraphic principles, radiometric dating methods are used in geochronology to establish the geologic time scale. Among the best-known techniques are radiocarbon dating, potassium\u2013argon dating and uranium\u2013lead dating.

Radiometric dating is a method used to date materials such as rocks or carbon, by comparing the abundance of a naturally occurring radioactive isotope within the material to the abundance of its decay products. This is possible because these decay at a known constant rate. The technique, first published in 1907 by Bertram Boltwood, is a major source of information about the absolute age of rocks, geological features, fossilized life forms, the Earth itself and a range of natural and man-made materials. Along with stratigraphic principles, radiometric dating methods are used in geochronology to establish the geologic time scale. Techniques include radiocarbon dating, potassium\u2013argon dating and uranium\u2013lead dating.
What is half-life in radioactive decay?

The half-life of a first-order reaction is a constant that is related to the rate constant for the reaction: t 1/2 = 0.693/ k. Radioactive decay reactions are first-order reactions. The rate of decay, or activity, of a sample of a radioactive substance is the decrease in the number of radioactive nuclei per unit time.

The half-life in radioactive decay refers to the time period required for a quantity to reduce to half of its initial value. This is a constant that is related to the rate constant for the decay, expressed by the formula: t 1/2 = 0.693/ k. Where k is the rate of decay, or activity of the radioactive substance. It represents the decrease in the number of radioactive nuclei per unit time.
What is plate tectonics?

Plate tectonics is the scientific theory that Earth's lithosphere comprises a number of large tectonic plates, which have been slowly moving since about 3.4 billion years ago. The model builds on the concept of continental drift, an idea developed during the first decades of the 20th century. Plate tectonics came to be accepted by geoscientists after seafloor spreading was validated in the mid-to-late 1960s. Earth's lithosphere, the rigid outer shell of the planet including the crust and upper mantle, is fractured into seven or eight major plates and many minor plates or \"platelets\". Where the plates meet, their relative motion determines the type of plate boundary: convergent, divergent, or transform. The relative movement of the plates typically ranges from zero to 10 cm annually. Faults tend to be geologically active, experiencing earthquakes, volcanic activity, mountain-building, and oceanic trench formation.

Plate tectonics is a scientific theory explaining the movement of the Earth's crust. It is broken up into various large and small pieces, known as tectonic plates. These plates have been moving slowly over the Earth's surface for billions of years. The movement of these plates can cause earthquakes, volcanic activity, the development of mountain ranges, and deep oceanic trenches. Their movement typically ranges from zero to 10 cms annually. The interactions between the tectonic plates can be categorized into convergent, divergent, or transform based on their relative motions.

What is a pipette?

What is a vacuum pump?

A vacuum pump is a device that removes gas particles from a sealed volume to create a partial vacuum. It was first invented in 1650 by Otto von Guericke.
What is a graduated cylinder?

A graduated cylinder, also known as a measuring cylinder or mixing cylinder, is a common piece of laboratory equipment used to measure the volume of a liquid. It has a narrow cylindrical shape. Each marked line on the graduated cylinder represents the amount of liquid that has been measured.

A graduated cylinder, known also as a measuring cylinder or mixing cylinder, is a piece of laboratory equipment utilized to measure the volume of a liquid. What is a separatory funnel?

[1] Typically, one of the phases will be aqueous, and the ...

A separatory funnel, also known as a separation funnel or sep funnel, is a laboratory tool used in liquid-liquid extractions. Its purpose is to separate the components of a mixture into two immiscible solvent phases with different densities. One of these phases is typically aqueous.
What is a rotary evaporator?

A rotary evaporator (rotavap) is a device used in chemical laboratories for the efficient and gentle removal of solvents from samples by evaporation. When referenced in the chemistry research literature, description of the use of this technique and equipment may include the phrase \"rotary evaporator\", though use is often rather signaled by ...

It is an enclosure featuring a movable sash window on one side that confines and removes gases and particulates either out of the area via a duct or back into the room through air filtration.
What is an autoclave?

An autoclave is a machine used to carry out industrial and scientific processes requiring elevated temperature and pressure in relation to ambient pressure and/or temperature. It is also employed in the chemical industry for tasks such as curing coatings, vulcanizing rubber, and conducting hydrothermal synthesis.
What is a microtome?

A microtome (from the Greek mikros, meaning \"small\", and temnein, meaning \"to cut\") is a cutting tool used to produce extremely thin slices of material known as sections, with the process being termed microsectioning.Important in science, microtomes are used in microscopy for the preparation of samples for observation under transmitted light or electron radiation.

What is a centrifuge?

A centrifuge is a device that uses centrifugal force to subject a specimen to a specified constant force, for example to separate various components of a fluid. This is achieved by spinning the fluid at high speed within a container, thereby separating fluids of different densities (e.g. cream from milk) or liquids from solids. It works by ...

A centrifuge is a device that separates components of a fluid. This is done by spinning the fluid at high speed inside a container, creating a centrifugal force. The centrifugal force allows for fluids of different densities to be separated, like cream from milk, or the separation of liquids from solids.
What is a balance?
balance: [noun] physical equilibrium. the ability to retain one's balance.

What is a pH meter?

In other words, the pH value provides quantitative information about the activity of an acid or base within a given solution.

A spectrometer ( / sp\u025bk\u02c8tr\u0252m\u026at\u0259r /) is a scientific instrument used to separate and measure spectral components of a physical phenomenon. What is a mass spectrometer?

Mass spectrometry (MS), also called mass spec, is an analytical technique that is used to measure the mass-to-charge ratio of ions. The results are presented as a mass spectrum, a plot of intensity as a function of the mass-to-charge ratio. The information this equipment produces is displayed like a graph known as a mass spectrum, which shows the intensity against the mass-to-charge ratio. It can be used on both pure samples and complex mixtures across various fields.
What is a flow cytometer?

Flow cytometry is a lab test used to analyze characteristics of cells or particles. What is a pipette?

A pipette (sometimes spelled as pipet) is a type of laboratory tool commonly used in chemistry and biology to transport a measured volume of liquid, often as a media dispenser.Pipettes come in several designs for various purposes with differing levels of accuracy and precision, from single piece glass pipettes to more complex adjustable or electronic pipettes.

What is a micropipette?

What is a microscope slide?

Typically the object is mounted (secured) on the slide, and then both are inserted together in the microscope for viewing.

A microscope slide is a thin flat piece of glass, typically 75 by 26 mm (3 by 1 inches) and about 1 mm thick. It is used to hold objects for examination under a microscope. Typically, the object is secured on the slide, and then both are inserted together in the microscope for viewing.

It serves the purpose of flattening the specimen for a better view and reduces the evaporation from the sample. If a stain or other liquid is added to the specimen, the cover slip helps to keep it in place on the specimen.

What is a reagent bottle?

Reagent bottles, also known as media bottles or graduated bottles, are containers made of glass, plastic, borosilicate or related substances, and topped by special caps or stoppers.
