In other words, frequencies for chemicals are measured for a 1 H nucleus of a sample from the 1 H or resonance of TMS.

A chemical shift in NMR (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance) spectroscopy is associated with the Larmor frequency of a nuclear spin relative to its chemical environment. Tetramethylsilane (TMS) is commonly used as a standard to determine the chemical shift of compounds, with a defined value of 0ppm. Hence, the frequencies of compounds are measured from the resonance of TMS.
What is tetrahedral geometry in chemical structure?

Tetrahedral molecular geometry. In a tetrahedral molecular geometry, a central atom is located at the center with four substituents that are located at the corners of a tetrahedron. The bond angles are cos \u22121 (\u2212 1\u20443) = 109.4712206...\u00b0 \u2248 109.5\u00b0 when all four substituents are the same, as in methane ( CH4) [1] [2] as well as its heavier ...

Tetrahedral geometry in chemical structure refers to the shape formed when a central atom is located at the center with four substituents that are located at the corners of a tetrahedron. The bond angles in this structure are approximately 109.5\u00b0. An example of a molecule with tetrahedral geometry is methane (CH4).
What is trigonal planar geometry in chemical structure?

Feature of trigonal planar geometry. This molecule is made up of 3 equally spaced sp 2 hybrid orbitals arranged at 120 0 angles. The shape of the orbitals is planar triangular. Since there is an atom at the end of each orbital, the geometry of the molecule is also trigonal planar. In this geometry the general formula is AX 3.

Trigonal planar geometry in a chemical structure refers to a molecule that is made up of 3 equally spaced sp 2 hybrid orbitals arranged at 120-degree angles. The shape of the orbitals is planar triangular, and since there is an atom at the end of each orbital, the geometry of the molecule is also trigonal planar. The general formula of this geometry is AX 3.
What is linear geometry in chemical structure?

Geometry of Molecules. Molecular geometry, also known as the molecular structure, is the three-dimensional structure or arrangement of atoms in a molecule. Understanding the molecular structure of a compound can help determine the polarity, reactivity, phase of matter, color, magnetism, as well as the biological activity.

Linear geometry in chemical structures refers to a three-dimensional arrangement of the atoms in a molecule where two outer atoms are in a straight line with the central atom. This linear shape contributes to the molecule's specific properties such as polarity, reactivity, phase of matter, color, magnetism, and biological activity.
What is a chemical bond?

A chemical bond is the association of atoms or ions to form molecules, crystals, and other structures. The bond may result from the electrostatic force between oppositely charged ions as in ionic bonds or through the sharing of electrons as in covalent bonds, or some combination of these effects.

A chemical bond is the association of atoms or ions that leads to formation of molecules, crystals, and other structures. This bond might be a result of the electrostatic force between oppositely charged ions, which is known as ionic bonds, or it could be due to the sharing of electrons, known as covalent bonds. There can also occur a combination of these effects.
What is a photovoltaic cell?

The photovoltaic effect is a process that generates voltage or electric current in a photovoltaic cell when it is exposed to sunlight.These solar cells are composed of two different types of semiconductors\u2014a p-type and an n-type\u2014that are joined together to create a p-n junction.By joining these two types of semiconductors, an electric field is formed in the region of the junction as ...

A photovoltaic cell is a device that generates voltage or electric current when exposed to sunlight due to the photovoltaic effect. The cell is made up of two different types of semiconductors, a p-type and an n-type, that are joined together to create a p-n junction. The joining of these semiconductors results in the formation of an electric field in the region of the junction.
What is nuclear power?

Nuclear power is the use of nuclear reactions to produce electricity. Nuclear power can be obtained from nuclear fission, nuclear decay and nuclear fusion reactions. Presently, the vast majority of electricity from nuclear power is produced by nuclear fission of uranium and plutonium in nuclear power plants. Nuclear decay processes are used in niche applications such as radioisotope thermoelectric generators in some space probes such as Voyager 2. Generating electricity from fusion power remains the focus of international research. Most nuclear power plants use thermal reactors with enriched uranium in a once-through fuel cycle. Fuel is removed when the percentage of neutron absorbing atoms becomes so large that a chain reaction can no longer be sustained, typically three years. It is then cooled for several years in on-site spent fuel pools before being transferred to long-term storage. The spent fuel, though low in volume, is high-level radioactive waste.

Nuclear power is derived from nuclear reactions to produce electricity. The majority of this energy comes from nuclear fission of uranium and plutonium in nuclear power plants. It can also be obtained from nuclear decay and nuclear fusion, with the latter being a primary focus of ongoing research. Nuclear power plants typically use thermal reactors with enriched uranium in a once-through fuel cycle, and the spent fuel (though low in volume) is considered high-level radioactive waste.
What is a polymer?

A polymer is a substance composed of very large molecules called macromolecules, which are multiples of simpler units called monomers. Polymers are found in nature and in synthetic materials, and they have various applications in biology, chemistry, and technology.

A polymer is a substance that consists of very large molecules known as macromolecules. These macromolecules are formed from simpler units known as monomers. Polymers are present in nature and in synthetic materials, and they have a wide range of applications in different fields like biology, chemistry, and technology.
What is a primary structure in protein?

Primary structure. The simplest level of protein structure, primary structure, is simply the sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain. For example, the hormone insulin has two polypeptide chains, A and B, shown in diagram below. (The insulin molecule shown here is cow insulin, although its structure is similar to that of human insulin.)

The primary structure of a protein is its simplest level of structure, which is the sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain. An example is insulin, which has two polypeptide chains, A and B, and this structure is similar between cow insulin and human insulin.
What is a secondary structure in protein?

The primary structure of a protein is linear. Secondary Structure: The secondary structure takes the chains (primary) and folds, or coils them. These parts attract to one another to form structures that have \u03b1(alpha)-helices and \u03b2(beta)-pleated sheets. These form as a result of hydrogen bonds between the peptide groups of the main (primary ...

The secondary structure of a protein represents the way its primary, linear arrangement folds or coils. This can result in structures like alpha-helices and beta-pleated sheets. This arrangement comes about due to hydrogen bonds formed between the peptide groups of the main chain.
What is a tertiary structure in protein?

The tertiary structure is the overall shape of the protein for which most are globular in shape, or fibrous - long and thin. Quaternary Structure: A quaternary structure is formed when two or more tertiary polypeptide chains form a single or full protein. Certain proteins may have a non-polypeptide structure, thus belonging to a prosthetic ...

The tertiary structure of a protein refers to its overall shape. Most proteins are either globular in shape or fibrous, which means they are long and thin. A quaternary structure is formed when two or more tertiary polypeptide chains form a single or full protein. Some proteins might also have a non-polypeptide structure, a component known as a prosthetic group.
What is quaternary structure in protein?

The tertiary structure is the overall shape of the protein for which most are globular in shape, or fibrous - long and thin. Quaternary Structure: A quaternary structure is formed when two or more tertiary polypeptide chains form a single or full protein. Certain proteins may have a non-polypeptide structure, thus belonging to a prosthetic ...

The quaternary structure of a protein refers to the formation of a full protein, which happens when two or more tertiary polypeptide chains come together. Some proteins may also have a non-polypeptide structure, called a prosthetic.
What is a protein?

A protein is a polyamide. Secondary structure: regularly repeating local structures stabilized by hydrogen bonds. The most common examples are the \u03b1-helix, \u03b2-sheet and turns. Because secondary structures are local, many regions of different secondary structure can be present in the same protein molecule.

A protein is a polyamide, which includes various structures. These structures, often referred to as secondary structures, include commonly known formations such as the alpha-helix, beta-sheet, and turns. These structures are locally placed, meaning that many regions of different secondary structure can exist within the same protein molecule.
What is an enzyme?

An enzyme is a substance that acts as a catalyst in living organisms, regulating the rate of chemical reactions without being altered. Learn about the chemical nature, nomenclature, and mechanism of enzyme action, as well as their applications and examples.

An enzyme is a substance that acts as a catalyst in living organisms, regulating the rate of chemical reactions without itself being altered. They are important for varied chemical reactions in the body and have applications in various fields.
What is a substrate?

Substrate is a noun that refers to a layer under something else, the base on which an organism lives, or a substance acted upon. Learn more about its usage, examples, and history from the Merriam-Webster dictionary.
A substrate refers to a layer that is underneath something else. It can also be the base on which an organism lives, or a substance that is acted upon.
What is catalyst?

Catalysis is the increase in rate of a chemical reaction due to an added substance known as a catalyst. Catalysts are not consumed by the reaction and remain unchanged after it. If the reaction is rapid and the catalyst recycles quickly, very small amounts of catalyst often suffice; mixing, surface area, and temperature are important factors in reaction rate. Catalysts generally react with one or more reactants to form intermediates that subsequently give the final reaction product, in the process of regenerating the catalyst. The rate increase occurs because the catalyst allows the reaction to occur by an alternative mechanism which may be much faster than the non-catalyzed mechanism. However the non-catalyzed mechanism does remain possible, so that the total rate can only increase in the presence of the catalyst and never decrease.

A catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself being consumed or changed by the reaction. It does this by enabling the reaction to occur through an alternative mechanism that is much faster than the non-catalyzed mechanism. Factors like mixing, surface area, and temperature can greatly affect the reaction rate. Even in small amounts, a catalyst can suffice especially if the reaction is rapid and the catalyst recycles quickly.
What is an active site of an enzyme?

The set of amino acids found in the active site, along with their positions in 3D space, give the active site a very specific size, shape, and chemical behavior. Thanks to these amino acids, an enzyme's active site is uniquely suited to bind to a particular target\u2014the enzyme's substrate or substrates\u2014and help them undergo a chemical reaction.

The active site of an enzyme is a region where the enzyme binds with its substrate or substrates. This site is composed of specific amino acids arranged uniquely in 3D space giving it a specific size, shape, and chemical behavior. This serves to enable the enzyme to assist particular substrates to undergo a chemical reaction.
What is an allosteric site of an enzyme?
The allosteric site is a site that allows molecules to either activate or inhibit (or turn off) enzyme activity. It's different than the active site on an enzyme, where substrates bind.

An allosteric site of an enzyme is a location which allows molecules to either activate or inhibit the enzyme's activity. This site is distinct from the active site on the enzyme where substrates bind.
What is enzyme-substrate complex?

The enzyme substrate complex is a temporary molecule formed when an enzyme comes into perfect contact with its substrate. Without its substrate an enzyme is a slightly different shape. The substrate causes a conformational change, or shape change, when the substrate enters the active site. The active site is the area of the enzyme capable of ...

The enzyme-substrate complex is a temporary molecule that is formed when an enzyme comes into perfect contact with its substrate. The substrate causes the enzyme to change its shape when it enters the enzyme's active site. The active site is the part of the enzyme that is capable of forming this complex with the substrate.
What is enzyme-product complex?

This forms the enzyme-substrate complex.The reaction then occurs, converting the substrate into products and forming an enzyme products complex. The products then leave the active site of the enzyme. Image modified from \"Enzymes: Figure 2,\" by OpenStax College, Biology, CC BY 3.0.

The enzyme-product complex is a state in the enzymatic reaction process where the reaction has occurred, and the substrate has been converted into products. These products are attached to the enzyme's active site, before subsequently leaving the active site.
What are co-factors?

Cofactor (biochemistry) The succinate dehydrogenase complex showing several cofactors, including flavin, iron-sulfur centers, and heme. A cofactor is a non- protein chemical compound or metallic ion that is required for an enzyme 's role as a catalyst (a catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction ).

A cofactor is a non-protein chemical compound or metallic ion that is required for an enzyme's activity as a catalyst. Catalysts increase the rate of a chemical reaction. An example of a cofactor is the succinate dehydrogenase complex, which includes several cofactors such as flavin, iron-sulfur centers, and heme.
What are co-enzymes?

Coenzyme Definition. A coenzyme is an organic non-protein compound that binds with an enzyme to catalyze a reaction. Coenzymes are often broadly called cofactors, but they are chemically different. A coenzyme cannot function alone, but can be reused several times when paired with an enzyme.

Co-enzymes are organic non-protein compounds that partner with an enzyme to catalyze a reaction. These co-enzymes cannot function on their own but can be reused multiple times once they are coupled with an enzyme.
What are vitamins?
Vitamins are nutrients that are found in the foods we eat. They're needed for functions such as growth, metabolism, and nervous system activities. Often, a health-promoting diet can provide all ...

Vitamins are nutrients found in the foods we eat. They are essential for various functions including growth, metabolism and activities of the nervous system. Typically, a health-promoting diet is able to provide all the necessary vitamins.
What are hormones?

Hormones are chemical messengers that coordinate different functions in your body by carrying messages through your blood to your organs, skin, muscles and other tissues. Learn about the endocrine system, the glands that make and release most of the hormones in your body, and the functions of hormones in metabolism, growth, sexual function, reproduction and more.

Hormones are chemical messengers that work to coordinate various functions within your body. They travel through the bloodstream to organs, skin, muscles, and other tissues. Hormones are produced and released mostly by the glands of the endocrine system and they are involved in various key bodily functions such as metabolism, growth, sexual function, reproduction and more.
What is receptor?

A receptor is a protein which binds to a specific molecule. The molecule it binds is known as the ligand. A ligand may be any molecule, from inorganic minerals to organism-created proteins, hormones, and neurotransmitters. The ligand binds to the ligand-binding site on the receptor protein.

A receptor is a protein that binds to a specific molecule, known as a ligand. Ligands can be any molecule, ranging from inorganic minerals to proteins, hormones, and neurotransmitters created by organisms. The ligand binds to the ligand-binding site on the receptor protein.
What are antagonists and agonists?

Agonist and Antagonists; discuss the key differences between the two. An agonist is a drug that binds to the receptor, producing a similar response to the intended chemical and receptor. Whereas an antagonist is a drug that binds to the receptor either on the primary site, or on another site, which all together stops the receptor from producing ...

An agonist is a substance that binds to a specific receptor and triggers a response in the cell, mimicking the action of a naturally occurring substance. Conversely, an antagonist is a substance that also binds to a receptor but instead inhibits the function of the receptor and prevents a biological response. It can bind to either the primary site or another site, ultimately blocking the receptor from producing a response.
What are inhibitors?

An enzyme inhibitor is a molecule that binds to an enzyme and blocks its activity. Enzymes are proteins that speed up chemical reactions necessary for life, in which substrate molecules are converted into products. [1] An enzyme facilitates a specific chemical reaction by binding the substrate to its active site, a specialized area on the ...

Inhibitors are molecules that bind to enzymes and block their activity. They facilitate specific chemical reactions by binding the substrate to their active sites. This is usually done by slowing down or entirely stopping these chemical reactions necessary for life where substrate molecules are converted into products.
What are activators?

Transcription factors are proteins that help turn specific genes \"on\" or \"off\" by binding to nearby DNA. Transcription factors that are activators boost a gene's transcription. Repressors decrease transcription. Groups of transcription factor binding sites called enhancers and silencers can turn a gene on/off in specific parts of the body.

Activators are types of transcription factors. These are proteins that boost a gene's transcription, i.e., they help to turn specific genes 'on'. They do this by binding to the DNA near the gene. This process also includes other types of transcription factors like repressors which decrease transcription, and others which can turn a gene on or off in specific parts of the body.
What is a reaction rate?

The speed of a chemical reaction may be defined as the change in concentration of a substance divided by the time interval during which this change is observed: rate = \u0394concentration \u0394time (2.5.2) (2.5.2) rate = \u0394 concentration \u0394 time. For a reaction of the form A + B \u2192 C A + B \u2192 C, the rate can be expressed in terms of the change in ...

A reaction rate of a chemical reaction is defined as the change in the concentration of a substance divided by the time interval during which this change is observed. It can be symbolically represented as: rate = \u0394concentration / \u0394time.
What is a rate equation?

Rate equation. In chemistry, the rate equation (also known as the rate law or empirical differential rate equation) is an empirical differential mathematical expression for the reaction rate of a given reaction in terms of concentrations of chemical species and constant parameters (normally rate coefficients and partial orders of reaction) only ...

A rate equation, also known as the rate law or empirical differential rate equation, is an empirical differential mathematical expression for the reaction rate of a given reaction in terms of concentrations of chemical species and constant parameters. The parameters usually include rate coefficients and partial orders of reaction.
What is order of reaction?

In order to determine the reaction order with respect to A, one must note in which experiment A is changing; that is, between experiments 1 and 2. Write a rate law equation based on the chemical reaction above. This is the rate law: rate = k[A]x[B]y rate = k [ A] x [ B] y.

The order of reaction refers to how the rate of a chemical reaction is affected by the concentration of its reactants. It's represented by the exponents in the rate law of the reaction, which is an equation of the form: rate = k[A]^x[B]^y, where A and B are the reactants, x and y are their respective orders of reaction, and k is the rate constant. The orders of reaction determine how changes in concentrations of A or B will affect the overall rate of reaction.
What is half-life of a reaction?

The half-life of a reaction is the time required for the reactant concentration to decrease to one-half its initial value. The half-life of a first-order reaction is a constant that is related to the rate constant for the reaction: t 1 /2 = 0.693/k. Radioactive decay reactions are first-order reactions. The rate of decay, or activity, of a ...

The half-life of a reaction is the amount of time that it takes for the concentration of the reactant to decrease to half of its initial value. The half-life of a first-order reaction, like radioactive decay, is a constant value that is related to the rate constant for the reaction by the equation t 1 /2 = 0.693/k.
What is the equilibrium constant?

The equilibrium constant of a chemical reaction is the value of its reaction quotient at chemical equilibrium, a state approached by a dynamic chemical system after sufficient time has elapsed at which its composition has no measurable tendency towards further change. For a given set of reaction conditions, the equilibrium constant is independent of the initial analytical concentrations of the reactant and product species in the mixture. Thus, given the initial composition of a system, known equilibrium constant values can be used to determine the composition of the system at equilibrium. However, reaction parameters like temperature, solvent, and ionic strength may all influence the value of the equilibrium constant. A knowledge of equilibrium constants is essential for the understanding of many chemical systems, as well as biochemical processes such as oxygen transport by hemoglobin in blood and acid\u2013base homeostasis in the human body.

The equilibrium constant of a chemical reaction is a value that represents the ratio of concentrations of products to reactants at a state of chemical equilibrium. The equilibrium constant depends on factors such as temperature, solvent, and ionic strength. It helps to determine the composition of the system at equilibrium and is crucial for understanding chemical systems, as well as biochemical processes like oxygen transport by hemoglobin in blood and acid-base homeostasis in the human body. It should be noted that for a given set of reaction conditions, the equilibrium constant is independent of the initial concentrations of the reactant and product species.
What is a reversible reaction?

A reversible reaction is a chemical reaction where the reactants form products that react together to give the reactants back. It is denoted by a double arrow in a chemical equation. Learn how reversible reactions work, what are their advantages and disadvantages, and see examples of reversible reactions in chemistry.

A reversible reaction is a chemical process where the reactants form products and these products react together to give back the reactants. This characterizing feature of reversible reactions is usually represented by a double arrow in chemical equations.
What is Law of Mass Action?

In chemistry, the law of mass action is the proposition that the rate of the chemical reaction is directly proportional to the product of the activities or concentrations of the reactants. It explains and predicts behaviors of solutions in dynamic equilibrium. Specifically, it implies that for a chemical reaction mixture that is in equilibrium, the ratio between the concentration of reactants and products is constant. Two aspects are involved in the initial formulation of the law: 1 the equilibrium aspect, concerning the composition of a reaction mixture at equilibrium and 2 the kinetic aspect concerning the rate equations for elementary reactions. Both aspects stem from the research performed by Cato M. Guldberg and Peter Waage between 1864 and 1879 in which equilibrium constants were derived by using kinetic data and the rate equation which they had proposed.

The Law of Mass Action in chemistry states that the rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the product of the activities or concentrations of the reactants. This law also provides an explanation and prediction for the behaviors of solutions in dynamic equilibrium, implying that for a chemical reaction mixture that is in equilibrium, the ratio between the concentration of reactants and products is constant. Two aspects, the equilibrium aspect which is about the composition of a reaction mixture at equilibrium, and the kinetic aspect which is about the rate equations for elementary reactions, are involved in the initial formulation of this law. These aspects originated from the research done by Cato M. Guldberg and Peter Waage between 1864 and 1879, where they derived equilibrium constants using kinetic data and the proposed rate equation.
What is dynamic equilibrium?

In chemistry, a dynamic equilibrium exists once a reversible reaction occurs. Substances transition between the reactants and products at equal rates, meaning there is no net change. Reactants and products are formed at such a rate that the concentration of neither changes. It is a particular example of a system in a steady state. In physics, concerning thermodynamics, a closed system is in thermodynamic equilibrium when reactions occur at such rates that the composition of the mixture does not change with time. Reactions do in fact occur, sometimes vigorously, but to such an extent that changes in composition cannot be observed. Equilibrium constants can be expressed in terms of the rate constants for reversible reactions.

Dynamic equilibrium, in both chemistry and physics, is a state where reactants and products transition back and forth at equal rates, maintaining a consistent concentration and composition. Despite ongoing reactions, there is no observable change in the system over time. This concept is a specific instance of a system in a steady state. The rates of these reactions help determine the equilibrium constants for reversible reactions.
What is Le Chatelier's principle?

Le Chatelier's principle, also called Chatelier's principle, is a principle of chemistry used to predict the effect of a change in conditions on chemical equilibrium. The principle is named after French chemist Henry Louis Le Chatelier, and sometimes also credited to Karl Ferdinand Braun, who discovered it independently. It can be defined as: If the equilibrium of a system is disturbed by a change in one or more of the determining factors the system tends to adjust itself to a new equilibrium by counteracting as far as possible the effect of the change In scenarios outside thermodynamic equilibrium, there can arise phenomena in contradiction to an over-general statement of Le Chatelier's principle. Le Chatelier's principle is sometimes alluded to in discussions of topics other than thermodynamics, but this is not a primary topic of the present article.

Le Chatelier's principle, also known as Chatelier's principle, is a chemical doctrine that helps predict how changes in conditions will impact a chemical equilibrium. This principle was devised by French chemist Henry Louis Le Chatelier and also independently discovered by Karl Ferdinand Braun. It states that when a system in equilibrium experiences a change in one or more determining factors, it attempts to adjust itself to a new equilibrium by counteracting the effect of the change to the greatest extent possible. Although this principle is mostly used in thermodynamics, it can also sometimes be referred in discussions from other fields.
What are exothermic and endothermic reactions?

Endothermic and exothermic reactions can be thought of as having energy as either a reactant of the reaction or a product. Endothermic reactions require energy, so energy is a reactant. Heat flows from the surroundings to the system (reaction mixture) and the enthalpy of the system increases (\\(\\Delta H\\) is positive). ...

Exothermic and endothermic reactions are different in terms of energy flow. In an endothermic reaction, energy is required and hence, energy is a reactant. The heat flows from the surroundings to the system, leading to an increase in the enthalpy of the system. In contrast, exothermic reactions release energy, so energy is a product of the reaction. The heat is flowing out from the system to the surroundings, resulting in a decrease in the enthalpy of the system.
What is oxidation?

Oxidation is the loss of electrons by a molecule, atom or ion in a chemical reaction. It can be caused by other species or by the oxidation state of the species. Learn how oxidation relates to reduction, redox reactions and historical definitions involving oxygen or hydrogen.

Oxidation is a chemical reaction that involves the loss of electrons by a molecule, atom, or ion. Interestingly, this could either be because of the interaction with other species or due to changes in the oxidation state of the species. This concept is particularly important for understanding redox reactions and some historical definitions that involve elements like oxygen or hydrogen.
What is reduction?

Examples of Reduction. The H + ions, with an oxidation number of +1, are reduced to H 2, with an oxidation number of 0, in the reaction : Another simple example is the reaction between copper oxide and magnesium to yield copper and magnesium oxide: Rusting of iron is a process that involves oxidation and reduction.

Reduction is a chemical process in which the oxidation number of an atom or ion decreases. An example of a reduction reaction is where H+ ions with an oxidation number of +1 are reduced to H2, with an oxidation number of 0. Another example is the reaction between copper oxide and magnesium to yield copper and magnesium oxide. This process also involves both oxidation and reduction.
What is an oxidizing agent?

An oxidizing agent (often referred to as an oxidizer or an oxidant) is a chemical species that tends to oxidize other substances, i.e. cause an increase in the oxidation state of the substance by making it lose electrons. Common examples of oxidizing agents include halogens (such as chlorine and fluorine), oxygen, and hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ).

An oxidizing agent, also known as an oxidizer or an oxidant, is a chemical species that oxidizes other substances. This means it causes an increase in the oxidation state of the substance by making it lose electrons. Common examples of oxidizing agents include halogens like chlorine and fluorine, oxygen, and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
What is a reducing agent?

In chemistry, a reducing agent (also known as a reductant, reducer, or electron donor) is a chemical species that \"donates\" an electron to an electron recipient (called the oxidizing agent, oxidant, oxidizer, or electron acceptor ).

A reducing agent, also known as a reductant, is a chemical species that donates an electron to an electron recipient. This recipient is referred to as the oxidizing agent, oxidant, oxidizer, or electron acceptor in chemistry.
What is Gibbs free energy?

In thermodynamics, the Gibbs free energy is a thermodynamic potential that can be used to calculate the maximum of reversible work that may be performed by a thermodynamic system at a constant temperature and pressure. The Gibbs free energy is the maximum amount of non-expansion work that can be extracted from a thermodynamically closed system; this maximum can be attained only in a completely reversible process. When a system transforms reversibly from an initial state to a final state, the decrease in Gibbs free energy equals the work done by the system to its surroundings, minus the work of the pressure forces.

Gibbs free energy is a thermodynamic potential used to calculate the maximum of reversible work that a thermodynamic system can perform at a constant temperature and pressure. This maximum can only be reached through a completely reversible process. When a system changes reversibly from an initial to a final state, the decrease in Gibbs free energy equals the work done by the system to its surroundings, excluding the work of the pressure forces.
What is enthalpy?

In thermodynamics, enthalpy, is the sum of a thermodynamic system's internal energy and the product of its pressure and volume. It is a state function used in many measurements in chemical, biological, and physical systems at a constant pressure, which is conveniently provided by the large ambient atmosphere. The pressure\u2013volume term expresses the work required to establish the system's physical dimensions, i.e. to make room for it by displacing its surroundings. The pressure-volume term is very small for solids and liquids at common conditions, and fairly small for gases. Therefore, enthalpy is a stand-in for energy in chemical systems; bond, lattice, solvation, and other chemical \"energies\" are actually enthalpy differences. As a state function, enthalpy depends only on the final configuration of internal energy, pressure, and volume, not on the path taken to achieve it. In the International System of Units, the unit of measurement for enthalpy is the joule.

Enthalpy is a term used in thermodynamics to describe the sum of a thermodynamic system's internal energy and the product of its pressure and its volume. It is often used in measurements in chemical, biological, and physical systems under a constant pressure. Essentially, enthalpy acts as a substitute for energy in chemical systems such as bond, lattice, solvation, and others, which are in reality enthalpy differences. The unit of measurement for enthalpy in the International System of Units is the joule.
What is entropy?

Entropy is a scientific concept that is most commonly associated with a state of disorder, randomness, or uncertainty. The term and the concept are used in diverse fields, from classical thermodynamics, where it was first recognized, to the microscopic description of nature in statistical physics, and to the principles of information theory. It has found far-ranging applications in chemistry and physics, in biological systems and their relation to life, in cosmology, economics, sociology, weather science, climate change, and information systems including the transmission of information in telecommunication. Entropy is central to the second law of thermodynamics, which states that the entropy of an isolated system left to spontaneous evolution cannot decrease with time. As a result, isolated systems evolve toward thermodynamic equilibrium, where the entropy is highest. A consequence of the second law of thermodynamics is that certain processes are irreversible.

Entropy is a scientific term mainly associated with disorder, randomness, or uncertainty. It is utilized in various fields like thermodynamics, statistical physics, information theory, and others. It is central to the second law of thermodynamics, which states that the entropy of an isolated system cannot decrease over time. Therefore, isolated systems evolve towards a state of thermodynamic equilibrium, where entropy is at its highest. This law also implies that certain processes cannot be reversed.
What is the significance of pH?

The body's pH balance refers to the chemical balance of acids and bases. The right pH balance is necessary for the body to function at its best. ... Although pH is often something only talked about in chemistry class, it does have significance in terms of the body's function. pH is a measure of how acidic or alkaline a substance is. The \"H ...
The significance of pH lies in its use to measure the acidity or alkalinity of a substance which is important for the body's functions. A balanced pH is vital for the body to operate optimally.
What is the normal pH of blood?

Blood pH is a measure of how acidic or basic your blood is. It ranges from 7.35 to 7.45, which is slightly alkaline or basic. Learn about the causes and effects of normal and abnormal blood pH, and how to test and treat it.
The normal pH of blood ranges from 7.35 to 7.45, which is slightly alkaline or basic.
What is the Bohr effect?

The Bohr effect is a phenomenon first described in 1904 by the Danish physiologist Christian Bohr. Hemoglobin's oxygen binding affinity is inversely related both to acidity and to the concentration of carbon dioxide. That is, the Bohr effect refers to the shift in the oxygen dissociation curve caused by changes in the concentration of carbon dioxide or the pH of the environment. Since carbon dioxide reacts with water to form carbonic acid, an increase in CO\u2082 results in a decrease in blood pH, resulting in hemoglobin proteins releasing their load of oxygen. Conversely, a decrease in carbon dioxide provokes an increase in pH, which results in hemoglobin picking up more oxygen.

The Bohr effect is a physiological phenomenon first described by Christian Bohr in 1904. It refers to hemoglobin's oxygen-binding affinity being inversely related to acidity and the concentration of carbon dioxide. In simpler terms, if there's an increase in carbon dioxide concentration, the blood becomes more acidic which causes hemoglobin proteins to release their load of oxygen. On the other hand, a decrease in carbon dioxide concentration leads to an increase in pH meaning the blood becomes less acidic. This results in hemoglobin taking up more oxygen.
What is Henderson-Hasselbalch equation?

The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation (Equation \\(\\ref{HH}\\)) is an approximation, with a certain region of validity. By its nature, it does not take into account the self-dissociation of water, which becomes increasingly important in dilute solutions. When concentrations reach somewhere around \\(10^{-5}\\ mol\\ L^{-1}\\) or lower, the true \\(pH ...

The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation is an approximation frequently used in chemistry and biology to determine pH or pOH of a solution. It is instrumental in studying acid-base balance in the human body. However, it is worth noting that this equation does not account for the self-dissociation of water, which becomes a significant factor in very dilute solutions.
What is pH titration?

The pKb of ammonia is 4.75 at 25\u00b0C. Answer. As shown in part (b) in Figure 17.4.3, the titration curve for NH3, a weak base, is the reverse of the titration curve for acetic acid. In particular, the pH at the equivalence point in the titration of a weak base is less than 7.00 because the titration produces an acid.

pH titration is a laboratory process used to determine the concentration of a chemical entity in a solution. When titrating a weak base such as ammonia, the titration curve is the reverse of the curve for a weak acid. Notably, the pH at the equivalence point in the titration of a weak base is less than 7.00 because the process results in an acid, as showcased when the pKb of ammonia is 4.75 at 25\u00b0C
What are buffers?

Introduction to Buffers. A buffer is a solution that can resist pH change upon the addition of an acidic or basic components. It is able to neutralize small amounts of added acid or base, thus maintaining the pH of the solution relatively stable.

Buffers are solutions that can resist pH change upon the addition of acidic or basic components. They can neutralize small amounts of added acid or base, thereby maintaining the pH of the solution relatively stable.
What is a coordinate bond?

Coordinate (Dative Covalent) Bonding. A coordinate bond (also called a dative covalent bond) is a covalent bond (a shared pair of electrons) in which both electrons come from the same atom. A covalent bond is formed by two atoms sharing a pair of electrons. The atoms are held together because the electron pair is attracted by both of the nuclei.

A coordinate bond, also known as a dative covalent bond, is a type of covalent bond where both electrons come from the same atom. This bond forms when two atoms share a pair of electrons. It holds the atoms together as the pair of electrons is attracted by both the nuclei.
What is stereochemistry?

Stereochemistry, a subdiscipline of chemistry, involves the study of the relative spatial arrangement of atoms that form the structure of molecules and their manipulation. The study of stereochemistry focuses on the relationships between stereoisomers, which by definition have the same molecular formula and sequence of bonded atoms, but differ in the geometric positioning of the atoms in space. For this reason, it is also known as 3D chemistry\u2014the prefix \"stereo-\" means \"three-dimensionality\". Stereochemistry spans the entire spectrum of organic, inorganic, biological, physical and especially supramolecular chemistry. Stereochemistry includes methods for determining and describing these relationships; the effect on the physical or biological properties these relationships impart upon the molecules in question, and the manner in which these relationships influence the reactivity of the molecules in question.

Stereochemistry is a subfield of chemistry that studies the spatial arrangement of atoms in molecules. This area focuses on the relationships between stereoisomers, which are molecules with the same molecular formula and sequence of bonded atoms, but they differ in their geometric positioning in space. Hence, it's often referred to as 3D chemistry. The study of stereochemistry extends to various areas including organic, inorganic, biological, physical, and supramolecular chemistry. It also includes determining and describing these relationships and their influence on the properties and reactivity of the molecules.
What is chirality?

Chirality is a property of asymmetry important in several branches of science. The word chirality is derived from the Greek \u03c7\u03b5\u03af\u03c1, \"hand\", a familiar chiral object. An object or a system is chiral if it is distinguishable from its mirror image; that is, it cannot be superimposed onto it. Conversely, a mirror image of an achiral object, such as a sphere, cannot be distinguished from the object. A chiral object and its mirror image are called enantiomorphs or, when referring to molecules, enantiomers. A non-chiral object is called achiral and can be superposed on its mirror image. The term was first used by Lord Kelvin in 1893 in the second Robert Boyle Lecture at the Oxford University Junior Scientific Club which was published in 1894: I call any geometrical figure, or group of points, 'chiral', and say that it has chirality if its image in a plane mirror, ideally realized, cannot be brought to coincide with itself. Human hands are perhaps the most recognized example of chirality.

Chirality is a property of asymmetry that's important in many science fields. An object or system is chiral if it's distinguishable from its mirror image, meaning it can't be superimposed onto it. In contrast, a mirror image of an object that isn't chiral (achiral), like a sphere, can't be distinguished from the original object. A chiral object and its mirror image are called enantiomorphs or, when referring to molecules, enantiomers. A familiar example of chirality is human hands - your left and right hand are mirror images, but they cannot be perfectly superimposed.
What are enantiomers?

Enantiomers are a pair of molecules that exist in two forms that are mirror images of one another but cannot be superimposed one upon the other. Enantiomers are in every other respect chemically identical. A pair of enantiomers is distinguished by the direction in which when dissolved in solution they rotate polarized light, either dextro (d or ...

Enantiomers are a pair of molecules that are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed one upon the other. They are chemically identical in every other respect. They are distinguished by the direction they rotate polarized light when dissolved in solution.
What are diastereomers?

Diastereomers vs. Enantiomers vs. Meso Compounds. Tartaric acid, C 4 H 6 O 6, is an organic compound that can be found in grape, bananas, and in wine. The structures of tartaric acid itself is really interesting. Naturally, it is in the form of (R,R) stereocenters. Artificially, it can be in the meso form (R,S), which is achiral.

Diastereomers are a type of stereoisomer that can be found in certain organic compounds such as tartaric acid, which is found in grapes, bananas, and wine. Natural tartaric acid is in the form of (R,R) stereocenters, while artificially, it can be in the meso form (R,S), which is achiral.
What is an optical isomer?

Optical isomerism. Optical isomers are named like this because of their effect on plane polarized light. Simple substances which show optical isomerism exist as two isomers known as enantiomers. A solution of one enantiomer rotates the plane of polarisation in a clockwise direction. This enantiomer is known as the (+) form.

An optical isomer is a type of isomer (a molecule that has the same molecular formula as another molecule, but which has a different chemical structure) where the difference in structure has to do with the difference in the spatial arrangement of atoms. The two forms, or enantiomers, of an optical isomer can rotate the plane of polarization of light in different directions. One enantiomer rotates it in a clockwise direction and is known as the (+) form.
What is plane polarized light?

Plane polarized light consists of waves in which the direction of vibration is the same for all waves. In the image above, you can see that a plane polarized light vibrates on only one plane. The process of transforming unpolarized light into polarized light is known as polarization. The devices like the polarizers you see are used for the ...

Plane polarized light consists of waves where the direction of vibration is the same for all waves. It vibrates on only one plane. The process that transforms unpolarized light into polarized light is called polarization. Devices such as polarizers are typically used for this process.
What is specific rotation?

In chemistry, specific rotation is a property of a chiral chemical compound. It is defined as the change in orientation of monochromatic plane-polarized light, per unit distance\u2013concentration product, as the light passes through a sample of a compound in solution. Compounds which rotate the plane of polarization of a beam of plane polarized light clockwise are said to be dextrorotary, and correspond with positive specific rotation values, while compounds which rotate the plane of polarization of plane polarized light counterclockwise are said to be levorotary, and correspond with negative values. If a compound is able to rotate the plane of polarization of plane-polarized light, it is said to be \"optically active\". Specific rotation is an intensive property, distinguishing it from the more general phenomenon of optical rotation.

Specific rotation is a characteristic of a chiral chemical compound. It portrays the change in orientation of monochromatic, plane-polarized light as it traverses through a sample of a compound in solution. The measure is given per unit distance-concentration product. If the compound rotates the plane of polarization clockwise, it is termed dextrorotary and has positive specific rotation values. Conversely, if the compound rotates the plane of polarization counterclockwise, it is levorotary and has negative values. A compound capable of rotating the plane of polarization of plane-polarised light is said to be 'optically active'. Specific rotation is an intensive property, which differentiates it from the broader phenomenon of optical rotation.
What is racemic mixture?

In chemistry, a racemic mixture or racemate, is one that has equal amounts of left- and right-handed enantiomers of a chiral molecule or salt. Racemic mixtures are rare in nature, but many compounds are produced industrially as racemates.

A racemic mixture, also known as a racemate, in chemistry, refers to a mixture that contains equal amounts of left- and right-handed enantiomers of a chiral molecule or salt. These mixtures are quite uncommon in nature, but are frequently produced industrially.
What is resolution of racemic mixture?

A racemic mixture is a 50:50 mixture of two enantiomers. Because they are mirror images, each enantiomer rotates plane-polarized light in an equal but opposite direction and is optically inactive. If the enantiomers are separated, the mixture is said to have been resolved.

Resolution of a racemic mixture refers to the process of separating the mixture into its constituent enantiomers. A racemic mixture contains two enantiomers in equal amounts, which rotate plane-polarized light in equal but opposite directions, making the mixture optically inactive. When these enantiomers are separated, we say the mixture has been resolved.
What is Geiger-Muller counter?

The sound of a geiger counter. A Geiger counter (/ \u02c8 \u0261 a\u026a \u0261 \u0259r /, GY-g\u0259r; also known as a Geiger-M\u00fcller counter or G-M counter) is an electronic instrument used for detecting and measuring ionizing radiation.It is widely used in applications such as radiation dosimetry, radiological protection, experimental physics and the nuclear industry.. It detects ionizing radiation such as alpha ...

A Geiger-Muller counter, often referred to as a G-M counter, is an electronic instrument used to detect and measure ionizing radiation. It's frequently used in fields like radiation dosimetry, radiological protection, experimental physics and the nuclear industry. It has the capability to detect ionizing radiation such as alpha particles.
What is a radioisotope?

A radioactive isotope, also known as a radioisotope, radionuclide, or radioactive nuclide, is any of several species of the same chemical element with different masses whose nuclei are unstable and dissipate excess energy by spontaneously emitting radiation in the form of alpha, beta, and gamma rays. Every chemical element has one or more radioactive isotopes.

A radioisotope, also known as a radionuclide or radioactive nuclide, is a species of a chemical element that has an unstable nucleus and dissipates excess energy by spontaneously emitting radiation in the form of alpha, beta, and gamma rays. Each chemical element has one or more radioactive isotopes.
What is a radioactive decay?

Radioactive decay (also known as nuclear decay, radioactivity, radioactive disintegration, or nuclear disintegration) is the process by which an unstable atomic nucleus loses energy by radiation.A material containing unstable nuclei is considered radioactive.Three of the most common types of decay are alpha, beta, and gamma decay.The weak force is the mechanism that is responsible for beta ...

Radioactive decay, also known as nuclear decay, radioactivity, radioactive disintegration, or nuclear disintegration, is a process where an unstable atomic nucleus loses energy by radiation. A material containing these unstable nuclei is deemed radioactive. The most common types of decay are alpha, beta, and gamma decay. The weak force is responsible for beta decay.
What is half-life of a radioisotope?

The radioisotopes used for imaging and treatment in medical sciences are usually synthesized and have a short half-life so that they may not persist in the body for an unnecessarily long time. For example, phosphorous-32, iodine-131, and technetium-99m have half-lives of 14.3 days, 8.1 days, and 6.0 hours, respectively.

The half-life of a radioisotope is the time it takes for half of the radioactive atoms present to decay. The half-life of radioisotopes varies greatly. As an example, phosphorous-32 has a half-life of 14.3 days, iodine-131 has a half-life of 8.1 days, and technetium-99m has a half-life of 6.0 hours.
What is gamma ray?

A gamma ray, also known as gamma radiation, is a penetrating form of electromagnetic radiation arising from the radioactive decay of atomic nuclei. It consists of the shortest wavelength electromagnetic waves, typically shorter than those of X-rays. With frequencies above 30 exahertz, each gamma ray imparts the highest photon energy of any form of electromagnetic radiation. Paul Villard, a French chemist and physicist, discovered gamma radiation in 1900 while studying radiation emitted by radium. In 1903, Ernest Rutherford named this radiation gamma rays based on their relatively strong penetration of matter; in 1900 he had already named two less penetrating types of decay radiation alpha rays and beta rays in ascending order of penetrating power. Gamma rays from radioactive decay are in the energy range from a few kiloelectronvolts to approximately 8 megaelectronvolts, corresponding to the typical energy levels in nuclei with reasonably long lifetimes.

Gamma rays, also known as gamma radiation, are a form of electromagnetic radiation originating from the radioactive decay of atomic nuclei. They consist of the shortest wavelength electromagnetic waves and are more powerful than X-rays. Gamma rays have frequencies above 30 exahertz and carry the highest photon energy of any form of electromagnetic radiation. They were discovered in 1900 by Paul Villard, a French chemist and physicist, while he was studying radiation emitted by radium. In 1903, Ernest Rutherford named this radiation 'gamma rays' due to their strong penetration ability. Alpha rays and beta rays, which are less penetrating types of decay radiation, were also named by Rutherford. The energy range of gamma rays from radioactive decay is typically a few kiloelectronvolts to approximately 8 megaelectronvolts, which corresponds to the typical energy levels in nuclei with reasonably long lifetimes.
What is a X-ray?

An X-ray is a quick, painless test that captures images of the structures inside the body \u2014 particularly the bones. X-ray beams pass through the body. These beams are absorbed in different amounts depending on the density of the material they pass through. Dense materials, such as bone and metal, show up as white on X-rays.

An X-ray is a quick, painless test that produces images of the structures inside your body, particularly your bones. It works by using X-ray beams which are absorbed in different amounts depending on the density of the material they pass through. Dense materials, such as bone and metal, appear white on the X-ray images.
What is an alpha particle?

Alpha particles, also called alpha rays or alpha radiation, consist of two protons and two neutrons bound together into a particle identical to a helium-4 nucleus. They are generally produced in the process of alpha decay but may also be produced in other ways. Alpha particles are named after the first letter in the Greek alphabet, \u03b1.The symbol for the alpha particle is \u03b1 or \u03b1 2+.

An alpha particle, also known as alpha ray or alpha radiation, is made up of two protons and two neutrons, which makes it identical to a helium-4 nucleus. They are usually produced during the process of alpha decay, but can also be produced in other ways. The alpha particle is denoted by the symbol \u03b1 or \u03b1 2+.
What is a beta particle?

A beta particle, also called beta ray or beta radiation (symbol \u03b2 ), is a high-energy, high-speed electron or positron emitted by the radioactive decay of an atomic nucleus during the process of beta decay. There are two forms of beta decay, \u03b2 \u2212 decay and \u03b2 + decay, which produce electrons and positrons respectively. [2]

A beta particle is a high-energy, high-speed electron or positron emitted by the radioactive decay of an atomic nucleus during the process of beta decay. There are two forms of beta decay, \u03b2- decay and \u03b2+ decay, which produce electrons and positrons respectively.
What is a neutron?

The neutron is a subatomic particle, symbol n or n 0, which has a neutral (not positive or negative) charge, and a mass slightly greater than that of a proton.Protons and neutrons constitute the nuclei of atoms.Since protons and neutrons behave similarly within the nucleus, they are both referred to as nucleons.Nucleons have a mass of approximately one atomic mass unit, or dalton, symbol Da.

A neutron is a subatomic particle that has a neutral charge, meaning it is not positive or negative. It has a mass slightly greater than that of a proton. Protons and neutrons are both referred to as nucleons because they behave similarly within the nucleus of an atom. They have a mass of approximately one atomic mass unit, or dalton.
What is a proton?

A proton is a stable subatomic particle, symbol. p. , H +, or 1 H + with a positive electric charge of +1 e ( elementary charge ). Its mass is slightly less than the mass of a neutron and 1,836 times the mass of an electron (the proton-to-electron mass ratio ). Protons and neutrons, each with masses of approximately one atomic mass unit, are ...

A proton is a stable subatomic particle with a positive electric charge equal to +1 e, which is an elementary charge. Its mass is slightly less than that of a neutron and around 1,836 times the mass of an electron. Protons and neutrons each have approximately the same mass, around one atomic mass unit.
What is an electron?

The electron (. e\u2212. or. \u03b2\u2212. ) is a subatomic particle with a negative one elementary electric charge. [13] Electrons belong to the first generation of the lepton particle family, [14] and are generally thought to be elementary particles because they have no known components or substructure. [1]

An electron is a subatomic particle with a negative one elementary electric charge. It belongs to the first generation of the lepton particle family, and is generally considered to be an elementary particle because it has no known components or substructure.
What is an isotope?

An isotope is one of two or more species of atoms of a chemical element with the same atomic number but different atomic masses and physical properties. Learn how isotopes are classified, how they are used, and how they differ from nuclides.
An isotope is one of two or more species of atoms of a chemical element that have the same atomic number but different atomic masses and physical properties.
What is a nuclide?

A nuclide (or nucleide, from nucleus, also known as nuclear species) is a class of atoms characterized by their number of protons, Z, their number of neutrons, N, and their nuclear energy state.. The word nuclide was coined by the American nuclear physicist Truman P. Kohman in 1947. Kohman defined nuclide as a \"species of atom characterized by the constitution of its nucleus\" containing a ...

A nuclide, also known as a nuclear species, is a class of atoms that is characterized by its number of protons, neutrons, and nuclear energy state. The term was coined by Truman P. Kohman in 1947. He defined nuclide as a 'species of atom characterized by the constitution of its nucleus'.
What is a nucleon?

Only resonances with a 3- or 4-star rating at the Particle Data Group (PDG) are included in this table. Due to their extraordinarily short ...

A nucleon is an excited state of nucleon particles, often corresponding to one of the quarks having a flipped spin state, or with different orbital angular momentum when the particle decays. These states are known as nucleon resonances.
What is an atomic nucleus?

The atomic nucleus is the small, dense region consisting of protons and neutrons at the center of an atom, discovered in 1911 by Ernest Rutherford based on the 1909 Geiger-Marsden gold foil experiment.

The atomic nucleus is the small, dense region at the center of an atom. It consists of protons and neutrons. It was discovered in 1911 by Ernest Rutherford following the 1909 Geiger-Marsden gold foil experiment.
What is a radionuclide?

A radionuclide ( radioactive nuclide, radioisotope or radioactive isotope) is a nuclide that has excess numbers of either neutrons or protons, giving it excess nuclear energy, and making it unstable. This excess energy can be used in one of three ways: emitted from the nucleus as gamma radiation; transferred to one of its electrons to release ...

A radionuclide, also known as radioactive nuclide, radioisotope or radioactive isotope, is a nuclide that has excess numbers of either neutrons or protons, giving it excess nuclear energy, making it unstable. This excess energy can be emitted from the nucleus as gamma radiation or transferred to one of its electrons.
What is a gamma spectroscopy?

Gamma-ray spectroscopy is the qualitative study of the energy spectra of gamma-ray sources, such as in the nuclear industry, geochemical investigation, and astrophysics. Gamma-ray spectrometry, on the other hand, is the method used to acquire a quantitative spectrum measurement.

Gamma-ray spectroscopy is a method used for the qualitative analysis of energy spectra of gamma-ray sources. This approach is widely used in different fields including nuclear industry, geochemical research, and astrophysics. Furthermore, Gamma-ray spectrometry is a specific technique to quantitatively measure the spectrum.
What is a radiometric dating?

Radiometric dating. Radiometric dating, radioactive dating or radioisotope dating is a technique which is used to date materials such as rocks or carbon, in which trace radioactive impurities were selectively incorporated when they were formed. The method compares the abundance of a naturally occurring radioactive isotope within the material to ...

Radiometric dating, also known as radioactive dating or radioisotope dating, is a technique used to date materials such as rocks or carbon. It does this by measuring the abundance of naturally occurring radioactive isotopes within the material, which were selectively incorporated when the material was formed.
What is carbon dating?

Radiocarbon dating is a method for determining the age of an object containing organic material by using the properties of radiocarbon, a radioactive isotope of carbon. The method was developed in the late 1940s at the University of Chicago by Willard Libby. It is based on the fact that radiocarbon is constantly being created in the Earth's atmosphere by the interaction of cosmic rays with atmospheric nitrogen. The resulting \u00b9\u2074 C combines with atmospheric oxygen to form radioactive carbon dioxide, which is incorporated into plants by photosynthesis; animals then acquire \u00b9\u2074 C by eating the plants. When the animal or plant dies, it stops exchanging carbon with its environment, and thereafter the amount of \u00b9\u2074 C it contains begins to decrease as the \u00b9\u2074 C undergoes radioactive decay. Measuring the proportion of \u00b9\u2074 C in a sample from a dead plant or animal, such as a piece of wood or a fragment of bone, provides information that can be used to calculate when the animal or plant died.

Carbon dating, also known as radiocarbon dating, is a method for determining the age of an object containing organic material. This process utilizes the properties of radiocarbon, a radioactive isotope of carbon. It was developed in the late 1940s by Willard Libby at the University of Chicago. This method is based on the fact that radiocarbon is created in the Earth's atmosphere via the interaction of cosmic rays with atmospheric nitrogen. The created radiocarbon combines with atmospheric oxygen to form radioactive carbon dioxide, which plants incorporate through photosynthesis. Animals then acquire radiocarbon by eating these plants. When a plant or animal dies, the exchange of carbon stops, and the contained radiocarbon begins to decrease due to radioactive decay. By measuring the proportion of radiocarbon in a sample from a dead plant or animal, one can calculate the time of their death.
What is uranium dating?

Uranium-lead dating. Uranium-lead dating, abbreviated U-Pb dating, is one of the oldest [1] and most refined of the radiometric dating schemes. It can be used to date rocks that formed and crystallised from about 1 million years to over 4.5 billion years ago with routine precisions in the 0.1-1 percent range. [2] [3]

Uranium-lead dating, also known as U-Pb dating, is one of the oldest and most refined radiometric dating schemes. It's typically used to date rocks that formed and crystallised from about 1 million years to over 4.5 billion years ago with routine precisions in the 0.1-1 percent range.
What is a tritium?

Tritium (from Ancient Greek \u03c4\u03c1\u03af\u03c4\u03bf\u03c2 (tr\u00edtos) 'third') or hydrogen-3 (symbol T or 3H) is a rare and radioactive isotope of hydrogen with half-life ~12.3 years. The nucleus of tritium (t, sometimes called a triton) contains one proton and two neutrons, whereas the nucleus of the common isotope hydrogen-1 ( protium) contains one proton and ...

Tritium, also known as hydrogen-3, is a rare and radioactive isotope of hydrogen. It has a half-life of approximately 12.3 years. The nucleus of tritium contains one proton and two neutrons, contrasting from the common isotope hydrogen-1 (protium) which contains just one proton.
What is nuclear fission?

Nuclear fission is a reaction in which the nucleus of an atom splits into two or more smaller nuclei. The fission process often produces gamma photons, and releases a very large amount of energy even by the energetic standards of radioactive decay. Nuclear fission was discovered on 19 December 1938 in Berlin by German chemists Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann. Physicists Lise Meitner and her nephew Otto Robert Frisch explained it theoretically in January 1939. Frisch named the process \"fission\" by analogy with biological fission of living cells. In their second publication on nuclear fission in February 1939, Hahn and Strassmann predicted the existence and liberation of additional neutrons during the fission process, opening up the possibility of a nuclear chain reaction. For heavy nuclides, it is an exothermic reaction which can release large amounts of energy both as electromagnetic radiation and as kinetic energy of the fragments.

Nuclear fission is a reaction where an atom's nucleus splits into two or more smaller nuclei, usually producing gamma photons and releasing a significant amount of energy. It was discovered in December 1938 by German chemists Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann and was theoretically explained by physicists Lise Meitner and Otto Robert Frisch in January 1939. It's an exothermic reaction, meaning it releases energy, which can be in the form of electromagnetic radiation or kinetic energy of the fragments. This process can potentially lead to a nuclear chain reaction due to the liberation of additional neutrons.
What is nuclear fusion?

Nuclear fusion is a reaction in which two or more atomic nuclei, usually deuterium and tritium, combine to form one or more different atomic nuclei and subatomic particles. The difference in mass between the reactants and products is manifested as either the release or absorption of energy. This difference in mass arises due to the difference in nuclear binding energy between the atomic nuclei before and after the reaction. Nuclear fusion is the process that powers active or main-sequence stars and other high-magnitude stars, where large amounts of energy are released. A nuclear fusion process that produces atomic nuclei lighter than iron-56 or nickel-62 will generally release energy. These elements have a relatively small mass and a relatively large binding energy per nucleon. Fusion of nuclei lighter than these releases energy, while the fusion of heavier nuclei results in energy retained by the product nucleons, and the resulting reaction is endothermic.

Nuclear fusion is a process where two or more atomic nuclei merge to form one or more different atomic nuclei and subatomic particles. This process, which happens in stars like our Sun, is responsible for releasing massive amounts of energy. Fusion reactions involving atomic nuclei lighter than iron-56 or nickel-62 will generally emit energy. Conversely, the fusion of heavier nuclei absorbs energy. The energy involved in either process is the result of the difference in nuclear binding energy between the atomic nuclei before and after the reaction.
What is a nuclear reactor?

A nuclear reactor is a device used to initiate and control a fission nuclear chain reaction or nuclear fusion reactions. Nuclear reactors are used at nuclear power plants for electricity generation and in nuclear marine propulsion. Heat from nuclear fission is passed to a working fluid ...

A nuclear reactor is a device that starts and controls a fission nuclear chain reaction or nuclear fusion reactions. It's primarily used at nuclear power plants for electricity generation and in nuclear marine propulsion. The heat generated from nuclear fission is transferred to a working fluid.
What is a critical mass?

A critical mass is a mass of fissile material that self-sustains a fission chain reaction. In this case, called criticality, k = 1. A steady rate of spontaneous fission causes a proportionally steady level of neutron activity. A supercritical mass is a mass which, once fission has started, will proceed at an increasing rate. [1]

A critical mass is the amount of fissile material that is enough to maintain a fission chain reaction. When this state, known as criticality, is achieved, the rate of spontaneous fission and corresponding neutron activity remains steady. If the mass is supercritical, the fission process will increase over time once it has started.
What is a chain reaction?

A chain reaction is a sequence of reactions where a reactive product or by-product causes additional reactions to take place. In a chain reaction, positive feedback leads to a self-amplifying chain of events. Chain reactions are one way that systems which are not in thermodynamic equilibrium can release energy or increase entropy in order to reach a state of higher entropy.

A chain reaction is a sequence of reactions where a reactive product or by-product initiates further reactions. This process, driven by positive feedback, leads to a self-amplifying chain of events allowing systems not in thermodynamic equilibrium to release energy or increase entropy, thus reaching a state of higher entropy.
What is a breeder reactor?

A breeder reactor is a nuclear reactor that generates more fissile material than it consumes. These reactors can be fueled with more-commonly available isotopes of uranium and thorium, such as uranium-238 and thorium-232, as opposed to the rare uranium-235 which is used in conventional reactors.

What is nuclear fuel?

Nuclear fuel is material used in nuclear power stations to produce heat to power turbines. Heat is created when nuclear fuel undergoes nuclear fission. Most nuclear fuels contain heavy fissile actinide elements that are capable of undergoing and sustaining nuclear fission. The three most relevant fissile isotopes are uranium-233, uranium-235 and plutonium-239. When the unstable nuclei of these atoms are hit by a slow-moving neutron, they frequently split, creating two daughter nuclei and two or three more neutrons. In that case, the neutrons released go on to split more nuclei. This creates a self-sustaining chain reaction that is controlled in a nuclear reactor, or uncontrolled in a nuclear weapon. Alternatively, if the nucleus absorbs the neutron without splitting, it creates a heavier nucleus with one additional neutron. The processes involved in mining, refining, purifying, using, and disposing of nuclear fuel are collectively known as the nuclear fuel cycle.

Nuclear fuel is a material used in nuclear power stations to produce heat that powers turbines. This heat is generated when nuclear fuel undergoes a process called nuclear fission. Commonly used nuclear fuels include fissile isotopes such as uranium-233, uranium-235, and plutonium-239. These isotopes have unstable nuclei that, when struck by a slow-moving neutron, often split into two 'daughter' nuclei and release additional neutrons. These additional neutrons can then split more nuclei, resulting in a self-sustaining chain reaction. In a nuclear reactor, this reaction is controlled. In a nuclear weapon, it's uncontrolled. Mining, refining, purifying, using, and disposing of nuclear fuel are collectively known as the nuclear fuel cycle.
What is nuclear waste?

Radioactive waste is a type of hazardous waste that contains radioactive material. Radioactive waste is a result of many activities, including nuclear medicine, nuclear research, nuclear power generation, nuclear decommissioning, rare-earth mining, and nuclear weapons reprocessing. The storage and disposal of radioactive waste is regulated by government agencies in order to protect human health and the environment. Radioactive waste is broadly classified into low-level waste, such as paper, rags, tools, clothing, which contain small amounts of mostly short-lived radioactivity, intermediate-level waste, which contains higher amounts of radioactivity and requires some shielding, and high-level waste, which is highly radioactive and hot due to decay heat, thus requiring cooling and shielding. In nuclear reprocessing plants about 96% of spent nuclear fuel is recycled back into uranium-based and mixed-oxide fuels.

What is radiotherapy?

Radiation therapy or radiotherapy is a treatment using ionizing radiation, generally provided as part of cancer therapy to either kill or control the growth of malignant cells. It is normally delivered by a linear particle accelerator. Radiation therapy may be curative in a number of types of cancer if they are localized to one area of the body, and have not spread to other parts. It may also be used as part of adjuvant therapy, to prevent tumor recurrence after surgery to remove a primary malignant tumor. Radiation therapy is synergistic with chemotherapy, and has been used before, during, and after chemotherapy in susceptible cancers. The subspecialty of oncology concerned with radiotherapy is called radiation oncology. A physician who practices in this subspecialty is a radiation oncologist. Radiation therapy is commonly applied to the cancerous tumor because of its ability to control cell growth.

Radiotherapy, also known as radiation therapy, is a cancer treatment that uses ionizing radiation to kill or control the growth of malignant cells. It is usually administered via a linear accelerator. This type of therapy can be curative if the cancer is localized to one area of the body and has not spread. In addition, it can be used as part of adjuvant therapy to minimize the risk of tumor recurrence after surgical removal of a primary malignant tumor. The medical subspecialty concerned with radiotherapy is known as radiation oncology, and a physician practicing in this field is a radiation oncologist.
What is radiation protection?

Radiation protection, also known as radiological protection, is defined by the International Atomic Energy Agency as \"The protection of people from harmful effects of exposure to ionizing radiation, and the means for achieving this\". Exposure can be from a source of radiation external to the human body or due to internal irradiation caused by the ingestion of radioactive contamination. Ionizing radiation is widely used in industry and medicine, and can present a significant health hazard by causing microscopic damage to living tissue. There are two main categories of ionizing radiation health effects. At high exposures, it can cause \"tissue\" effects, also called \"deterministic\" effects due to the certainty of them happening, conventionally indicated by the unit gray and resulting in acute radiation syndrome.

What is ionizing radiation?

Ionizing radiation, including nuclear radiation, consists of subatomic particles or electromagnetic waves that have sufficient energy to ionize atoms or molecules by detaching electrons from them. Some particles can travel up to 99% of the speed of light, and the electromagnetic waves are on the high-energy portion of the electromagnetic spectrum. Gamma rays, X-rays, and the higher energy ultraviolet part of the electromagnetic spectrum are ionizing radiation, whereas the lower energy ultraviolet, visible light, nearly all types of laser light, infrared, microwaves, and radio waves are non-ionizing radiation. The boundary between ionizing and non-ionizing radiation in the ultraviolet area cannot be sharply defined, as different molecules and atoms ionize at different energies. The energy of ionizing radiation starts between 10 electronvolts and 33 eV. Typical ionizing subatomic particles include alpha particles, beta particles, and neutrons.
